story: The opposition party claimed on Monday it was planning to bring forward its amendments to Michael Gove&rsquos fisheries bill - which will govern the fishing sector after the UK leaves the EU - claiming not enough has been done to &ldquoprotect smaller industry. Small boats provide the bulk of jobs in the catching sector and contribute to the economy of coastal towns around the country. But Labour claimed independent boats have just six percent of the total British quota, with much of the rights to fish owned by a handful of larger firms. French fisherman claims Brexit could 'BANKRUPT him'                Fishing powers unveiled &ndash post-Brexit UK WILL take back control Shadow fisheries minister Luke Pollard said: &ldquoBy ignoring the needs of smaller fishing fleets, this Government is betraying British fishing.Michael Gove could take action to redistribute fishing quota now if he wanted to, but he is failing by not delivering quota reallocation in the Fisheries Bill.Labour is setting out our vision for Britain to have the most sustainable fisheries in the world.That means a greater focus on ensuring fish stocks are healthy, that there is proper enforcement and a fairer distribution of fishing quota.Mr Pollard (L) wants to make amendments to Mr Gove's Fisheries Policy to protect small boats (Image: )Brexit news Labour have criticised Mr Gove's Fisheries Policy for not supporting independent boats (Image: )&ldquoLabour will ensure that fishing quota isn't monopolised by the few.Rebecca Newsom, head of politics at Greenpeace UK, said: This is the first serious, concrete and achievable commitment to reform the UK's fishing industry we have seen from any political party since the EU referendum.Labour's commitment to reallocate existing fishing quota - not just any new quota following an exit agreement - is a huge step in acknowledging that the current system is broken and sticking plasters won't work.This approach would give due weight to social, economic and environmental criteria in the distribution of fishing quota and would see huge gains for coastal communities and our environment.

story: The Labour peer has been a vocal opponent of Brexit and has long campaigned to hold a second referendum on the final terms of the withdrawal agreement struck with the European Union. story: The Prime Minister will have to settle five key issues as rebels in Westminster and across the European Union&rsquos remaining 27 demand a number of eleventh-hour changes.&nbspMr Juncker, the EU&rsquos most senior official, will host Mrs May for afternoon tea later today as the Brexit negotiations reach the highest political stage. UK will BREAK UP and Scotland should rejoin the EU, says Spain                BREXIT LIVE: Theresa May warned bring something NEW back from EUThe end date of a possible extended transition period, Gibraltar, fishing, future frictionless trade and guarantees on creating a level playing field between the UK and EU will have to be decided upon before the special Brexit summit on Sunday, when European leaders are expected to endorse the two documents.&nbspThe 585-page orce deal has been concluded between EU and UK officials and is unlikely to change.&nbspMost of their work will focus on the &ldquopolitical declaration setting out the framework for the future relationship, which was published alongside the withdrawal deal last week.The seven-page document has been &ldquostabilised and has over trebled in size since it&rsquos release, according to one EU diplomat familiar with the negotiations.&nbspBrexit news: Theresa May and Jean-Claude Juncker must resolve five issues in talks today (Image: )A late-night meeting between EU27 ambassadors and members of the bloc&rsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier&rsquos team highlighted the remaining issues to be solved.Spanish opposition to the withdrawal agreement and political declaration, which culminated in the country&rsquos prime minister Pedro Sanchez threatening to veto the deal, has &ldquoblocked talks, according to another source.Madrid has raised opposition to two clauses in the 585-page withdrawal agreement, agreed by Theresa May last week, during several crunch Brexit meetings of the EU27 in Brussels.Spain has placed demands for an added commitment in the 23-page &ldquopolitical declaration setting out the framework for the future relationship, which allows Madrid a veto over whether future trade and security treaties will apply to Gibraltar.                Lord Adonis LAUGHED AT as he laments 162 HOURS of anti-Brexit arguing                Sturgeon builds anti-Brexit 'coalition of opposition' on London tripMadrid has taken issue with Article 184 of the withdrawal agreement, which states that the United Kingdom and EU will use the transition period to &ldquouse their best endeavours to negotiate expeditiously the agreements governing their future relationship referred to in the political declaration.Its government believes this clashes with Article 3 in the draft treaty, which sets out the territorial scope of the negotiations, will cover Gibraltar and other British overseas territories.EU negotiations have proposed Gibraltar be included in the political declaration but UK officials have so far rejected the move.Brussels is also waiting on the end date for a possible extension to the agreed 21-month transition period, which is one of two options that could be used to ensure the controversial Irish backstop is never used.Michel Barnier has failed to reach a conclusion on Spain's opposition to the deal of Gibraltar (Image: )At a meeting of EU ambassadors last Sunday, Mr Barnier floated the possibility of the one-off extension running until December 30, 2022.His idea would allow EU and UK officials two extra years of negotiations to ensure a future trade deal avoids a hard border, but would mean the UK wouldn&rsquot have left the Bloc until six years after the 2016 referendum result.Brussels awaits an answer from Mrs May on what an acceptable extension date could be, she has previously hinted just a &ldquocouple of months would be needed.Fishing has also proved a contentious issue amongst member states since the publication of the withdrawal agreement, which essentially pushed the issue into the political declaration.The Prime Minister will also have to pitch an end date for a possible transition extension (Image: )France has argued that EU fishing boats should be allowed access to British waters if the future trade deal allows the UK access to the bloc&rsquos single market.Spain, Belgium, Denmark and Portugal have also voiced concerns that the draft treaty did not include a promise on European fishing rights.Britain is suggesting a Norway-style agreement for fishing, which would allow its Government to negotiate reciprocal access with inidual countries.&nbspItaly, the Netherlands, Denmark and Germany have expressed concerns that the EU&rsquos offer of a &ldquobackstop customs union will hand Britain an economic advantage if it becomes the basis for a future trade deal.&nbspThe countries are pushing for guarantees that will ensure Britain will have to align with EU regulations by inserting so-called &ldquoevolution clauses into the future deal.And finally, Britain has demanded &ldquofrictionless trade of goods be a key pillar of the future relationship.But EU countries are pushing back against the prospect, insisting only truly frictionless trade should be offered to members of its single market and customs union.Once these issues are hammered out between Mrs May and Mr Juncker, there will be a number of future negotiations between Mr Barnier, EU capitals and London ahead of the November 25 summit.EU leaders will then hold a number of talks before endorsing the deal, which still may prove trickier than expected.

title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. title: im a celebrity noel edmonds
story: With or without his rehab ­certicate. Kick ball, change and turn. Can you do that ”“I’m not allowed.”Not even the kick balls bit Shame. He needs someone to calm him down.Although, as horrendous as it must be to live with, I don’t mind Barrowman on I’m A Celeb, as the show does need a massive irritant to get under everyone’s skin.On similar grounds, I also welcome EastEnders’ Rita Simons, who looks like she might have a tantrum or two in her, Nick Knowles, who will be incapable of stling his Sir Galahad complex, and Harry Redknapp, just because he’s Harry Redknapp.Of the others The public jury’s probably still out on Emily Atack and The Chase Governess Anne Hegerty, who “used to be a Brownie”, as well as eating a lot of them.Mentally, though, I have already completely written off Coronation Street’s Sair Khan, some bloke off Hollyoaks, The Vamps’ James McVey and X Factor’s Fleur East, who arrived dressed as a dispatch rider for the first episode.Possibly for the very good reason she’s now working as one.This might sound like a hasty and fairly damning assessment, I realise, but compared to some series, four solidly promising bookings isn’t actually a bad .What it very clearly needs, though, is Edmonds, because, without him, Sunday’s opening episode, for all its high adrenaline thrills, became a bit of a drag.It usually does, of course, as the celebs haven’t yet let their guard drop.But, in this instance it meant the spotlight fell on Holly Willoughby, and you quickly realised Dec hasn’t had to work this hard since he tried bouncing jokes off Hogan the Koala.Just as Edmonds could turn out to be a massive disappointment, Holly Willoughby could get the hang of I’m A Celeb, obviously.At the moment, though, her one signicant contribution came after the parachuting challenge when she asked: “How come Shane had a helmet and Emily didn’t ”’Cos the bloke was doing all the hard work and she was just hanging around.Buckle up, Dec.Alastair Campbell’s far-too-frequent Good Morning Britain appearances always proving as welcome as a turd in a swimming pool.Strictly stars forever banging on about reaching Blackpool without ever mentioning it means they get paid more.Every wretched, product-placing second of the entertainment on Friday’s Children In Need.And particularly EastEnders’ big song-and-dance routine, which had the Disney Company’s Angela Affinita claiming: “We have Letitia Dean actually interacting with Mickey Mouse.”Good luck with that one, Mickey.IF you want to know just how brutally British republicans would mistreat the Royal Family,they ever came to power, just take a look at what those who claim to love them the most do to the Windsors now.Stuff like We Are Most Amused And Amazed, a th birthday tribute, hosted by Armstrong  Miller, on ITV, that probably left the future King Charles III thinking Charles I got off lightly.Two hours of canned laughter and pick-a-card-any-card magical tw*ttery with the likes of Sandi Toksvig, who took  seconds to remind us she’s gay, Omid Djalili, who took an entire  seconds to remind us he’s Iranian, and Rowan Atkinson, who rather set the evening’s tone by announcing: “As the more perceptive of you will have noticed, this is hell.”There was a family of German illusionists as well, which I thought was a bit insensitive, given the royal circumstances, plus Sooty  Sweep and a lot of grovelling from randoms, like Cheryl Tweedy and Kylie Minogue.Presumably because they could both be guaranteed to keep a straight face when describing the birthday boy as “a style icon” and “philanthropist”.Then, at the end of it all, dear old Charles shuffled on, waved and thanked everybody.And he may even have meant every syllable of it as well, given that Alexander Armstrong thrilled the Palladium crowd by deciding not to sing.Truly, the Royal Family is the most wondrous thing.Jenny Eclair: “The last thing any woman needs, during or after the menopause, is a bothersome vagina.”Tough, you’ve got one for another  minutes.MEANWHILE, desperate times call for desperate means at the rugby, as England trail Japan - and Sir Clive Woodward suggests: “We’ve got to start using our physicality, just outside the rucks, to suck these Japanese guys.”A WELCOME antidote to all of the lazy, repetitive, biased, hideously self-satisfied and right-on comedy broadcast by the BBC and Channel  finally reappeared, on Saturday night.Michael McIntyre’s Big Show, on BBC, which has to be the most perfectly judged hour of television, all year.A quota-free joy that’s warm, funny and has mainstream appeal, without ever being too cloying, safe, predictable or slick, as you will have noticed when Lionel Blair completely sabotaged the “Unexpected Star” reveal, in a pop-up Zimmer frame shop, with -year-old David Owen.“Say hello to David,” McIntyre whispered into his ear-piece.“Hello David!”Pause. “How does he know my name’s David ”Well, quite. Among his other gts, though, Michael McIntyre, above, has the ability to charm and ad-lib his way out of these situations, which gives his Big Show a seat-of-its-pants feel, despite being one of the most carefully structured formats on television.As anyone with a brain can see, in fact, it should be the blueprint for almost everything BBC comedy does.So I can pretty much guarantee, this time next year, Have I Got News, The Mash Report and Frankie Boyle’s New World Order will still be telling us how much they hate Brexit and Donald Trump and someone from the BBC, on £, a year, will be assuring licence-payers: “Sara Pascoe is the future of comedy.”Pointless Celebrities: “Hi, I’m Luisa Omielan and I’m a comedian.” Bless.And Good Morning Britain, Susanna Reid: “I don’t think the word ambition applies to me. title: vapers popcorn lung ecigarettes
story: Flavoured e-cigarettes are increasing in popularity, prompting warnings they are encouraging teenagers to take up vaping and getting them hooked on nicotine.Last week American company Juul announced it would temporarily pull some flavoured e-cigarettes from stores in the US until shops agree to adopt new age restrictions to ensure customers are at least  before they buy an e-cigarette.Juul was set to sell e-cigarettes at , Sainsburys stores in the UK from November .But its not just underage smoking that poses a risk with e-cigarettes - a chemical found in some flavours have been linked to an irreversible lung condition.Diacetyl, a chemical that creates a buttery flavour, has been linked to a condition called obliterative bronchiolitis, dubbed popcorn lung because of the high levels of disease found in workers from factories that used the chemical in microwave popcorn.The condition causes causes inflammation, scarring and constriction of the bronchioles –the tubes through which air passes from your nose or mouth to your lungs.Diacetyl is used in a number of buttery flavours like cupcake and candy floss.Over time the inflammation associated with popcorn lung causes the tissues and airways in the organ to scar and narrow, leaving sufferers with breathing dficulties.The symptoms may seem subtle to begin with, so can be easy to over look, they include wheezing, a dry cough, shortness of breath, unexplained exhaustion, rapid breathing, persistent skin, eye or mouth irritation.According to a Hard University in , Hard University, there is a direct link between diacetyl in e-cigarettes and popcorn lung.The study tested  types of flavoured e-cigs – specically choosing flavours that would be appealing to young people.Out of the  flavours tested,  of them had above the recommended level of diacetyl, leading scientists to conclude that urgent action is recommended to further evaluate this potentially widespread exposure via flavoured e-cigarettes.A pamphlet released by the US Surgeon Generals office also warned of the dangers of diacetyl in e-cigs, linking it to popcorn lung.But the Hard University analysis was done on e-cigarettes in the US, where diacetyl is allowed in vaping products.In the UK the chemical is banned, so its unlikely vapes youve bought here will contain the chemical.According to a Public Health Englandblog, Public Health Matters, its a myth that smoking e-cigarettes puts users at risk of popcorn lung.But that doesnt mean flavours containing the chemical cant be bought online from the US.One of the most commonly held concerns is that e-cigarettes might cause popcorn lung, PHE said.This came about because some flavourings used in e-liquids to provide a buttery flavour contain the chemical diacetyl, which at very high levels of exposure has been associated with the serious lung disease bronchiolitis obliterans.The condition gained its popular name because it was initially observed among workers in a popcorn factory.However, diacetyl is banned as an ingredient from e-cigarettes and e-liquids in the UK.It had been detected in some e-liquid flavourings in the past, but at levels hundreds of times lower than in cigarette smoke. Even at these levels, smoking is not a major risk factor for this rare disease.MPs have previously called for e-cigarettes to be free on the NHS as a stop smoking device.E-cigarettes are less harmful than conventional smoking and the two should not be treated as the same, according to a report by the Science and Technology Committee .Public Health England estimates suggest e-cigarettes are at least  per cent less harmful than smoking.Around . million Brits use e-cigarettes, and its thought , use them as an aid to stop smoking.A report from the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Vapingtoday sugguests employers should provide designated indoor vaping areas - including in the Houses of Parliament.They want vaping to be more acceptable around the workplace with proper vaping policies for businesses and public places to be put in place in a bid to tackle misunderstandings about the practice

story: They say searches for serious health conditions have increased by thousands of percentage points over the last three years.UK search volumes for terms such as how to know chest pains are serious have risen by , per cent from  to , analysis of Google data has found.And searches for keywords such as sciatica, acne and IBS plus the word treatment are now searched more than , times on average every year since .Stomach ache and aching legs were also found to top online searches, with an average of , and , searches yearly since .GP near me was googled , times between January and August alone this year.Hannah Sims, product manager for Perkbox Medical, which commissioned the research, said: “The NHS has been looking after the health of the nation for  years now.“It’s a wonderful system, but it isn’t without its challenges, particularly in primary care.“Currently, over one million people a week in the UK struggle to get themselves seen by a doctor when they need it.“GP surgeries tend to only be open during the usual working hours and are stretched to fit everyone in, pushing appointment waiting times to around two weeks.“Similarly, the average health insurance premium in the UK costs £,.The NHS lists hypochondria as health anxiety. According to the health organisation, it is commonly listed as having the following symptoms:Anxiety itself can cause symptoms like headaches or a racing heartbeat, and you may mistake these for signs of illness.“On top of that, there’s the admin involved with sorting it all out – wading through pages of jargon, comparing dferent, often confusing policies, conducting a full census of your staff and making big decisions about what you can and can’t afford to cover.It’s not an easy world to navigate in, and it’s no wonder busy employers and HR leaders back away.”The research also found that the number of Brits self-diagnosing themselves using Google is on the rise.How to knowchest pains are serious , was among the most searched terms with , average searches from January - August this year.How to get rid of back pain , received , average searches in the same period, and how to get rid of stomach pain , garnered , average searches.Sims added: “Many of these symptoms account for key causes of absenteeism at work, which costs the UK economy £billion per year.“And it makes sense, when waiting times are often long and employers aren’t financially able to provide their staff with an alternative route to see a doctor, people naturally look for a quick fix solution, googling their symptoms and getting some rest from home, or, worse, falling victims to ‘presenteeism’ at work.“Perkbox Medical is the first private healthcare product designed to focus specically on the areas where the NHS is particularly challenged - the most obvious one being primary care .“It’s an affordable solution that is tiered, making at least some level of health cover available to every UK business and giving employers an extra layer of flexibility.”

story: Amna Saleem tweeted the question to her followers who swtly offered their two cents on the contentious argument.Amna wrote: I will get back to writing in a sec but help me settle something - when you eat a digestive chocolate biscuit you eat it with the chocolate face down, right  So you can enjoy maximum chocolate. title: skeleton ancient egyptian woman unborn baby inside 3700 years
story: The woman, believed to have been about  years old, was due to give birth to the near-term baby, which was found in a head-down position, say researchers.Inside her tomb, uncovered near Aswan in title: no deal mars bar brexit jane moore
story: The operative word being “could”, of course. Same with Dairy Milk and Picnic bars too, apparently.Whatever, surely it’s a win-win situation  No more being bossed about by unelected Eurocrats and help tackle the obesity tooth rot crisis at the same time. But really, does anyone actually believe this Project Fear twaddle  No one has yet suggested that “no deal will see an end to Brussels sprouts”, but it can only be a matter of time.Meanwhile, we are still being peddled the prospect of medication piling up at the border, the entire City of London decamping to Paris, flights being grounded at the stroke of midnight on March , gridlocked motorwaysand “civil unrest”.Enough already. Like .million others, I voted for Brexit on the basis thatthe EU wouldn’t give us a mutually beneficial deal then we would simply leave without one.It’s now clear that, despite the clear mandate from . per cent of the British people that they want out, the painful preication of Mrs May’s “negotiations”has told the Brussels Eurocrats that our government is wavering on that mindset and, consequently, they feel they have us over an imported barrel.So it’s time to show them that they don’t — by openly preparing for no deal. After all, the notion that Merkel, Macron et al will bite off their own electorate’s noses to spite Britain’s volte face on EU membership is an absolute nonsense.In a letter to The Times yesterday, the chairman of pub chain JD Wetherspoon, Tim Martin, wrote: “The great urban myth, promoted by advocates of the deadly exchange rate mechanism, the euro and Remain, is that a ‘deal’ with the EU is a prerequisite of future prosperity.”The reality, he says, is that no deal would allow us to join successful countries such as Canada, Singapore, Israel and Australia in the free-trading world and “by slashing the EU’s , protectionist tarfs, shop prices will fall, with no loss to the Treasury, since tarf income is currently remitted to Brussels”.On top of that, we won’t have to pay the £billion orce bill, will regain control of our fishing waters, borders and laws and, ultimately, all have more money in our pockets. Or, in John Sergeant and Ann Widdecombe’s case, common moths in freefall after a battering from a tea towel.But former Pussycat Doll Ashley is used to performing complicated dance routines in front of huge crowds and, therefore, oozed confidence and expertise from the get go.Little wonder since, according to her former dance teacher in the US, she was taught “all dferent styles of dance” from the age of eight to  and once had an introduction to ballroom training by an elite dance company at summer school.So yes, she’s undoubtedly the best, with former Steps trouper Faye Tozer not far behind. But the true Strictly stars are all the others who improve each week despite being way outside their comfort zone.FOLLOWING the shocking attack of a female PC being karate-kicked to the ground by a thug, the flippant commentary accompanying the footage is indeed sickening.But at least the film might help secure a prosecution and hopefully prove a turning point in how we take back control of our lawless streets.Because the real problem here is the fact that thugs clearly don’t fear the consequences of their actions.So may I humbly suggest that it’s high time the Home Office toughens up and shows, not tells, our hard-pressed police that they now have the power and support they need from on high to do their job effectively.CHECK out poo guru Gillian McKeith out on the town with her smiling -year-old daughter Skylar.Considering my daughters won’t be seen dead with meI wear anything more risqué than a baggy polo neck and tweed maxi skirt, she’s very fortunate indeed.THE £. title: scientists alzheimers vaccine halve cases
story: DNA coding in the new jab triggers an immune response which prevents the build up of two toxic proteins that kill brain cells.In tests on mice it delayed the progression of the incurable disease — which affects up to , Brits — without causing any nasty side effects.Previous human trials of other vaccines have caused brain swelling.But the new jab is injected in the skin — not muscle like earlier drugs — which triggers a dferent immune response.The experts reckon the jab could be cheaper than other treatments which currently only control the symptoms.Lead researcher Dr Roger Rosenberg, director of the Alzheimer’s Disease Centre at the University of Texas, said: “This study is the culmination of a decade of research that has repeatedly demonstrated that this vaccine can effectively and safely target in animal models what we think may cause Alzheimer’s disease.”Researcher Dr Doris Lambracht-Washington, of the University of Texas, said: “If the onset of the disease could be delayed by even five years, that would be enormous for the patients and their families. The number of dementia cases could drop by half.”The Alzheimer’s Society said the jab could be a “signicant step” in tackling dementia.Dr Sara Imarisio, Head of Research at Alzheimer’s Research UK, said: “Vaccinations work by triggering the body’s immune system to arm itself against a potential threat, and have been explored by dementia researchers before in the search for new treatments. This approach has only been tested in mice so far, so it is still early days and scientists will need to further test these vaccines to ensure their safety before they can begin a clinical trial in people.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: journey to journalism sarah jones mp
story: The Journey to Journalism programme will give BAME teenagers in Croydon the chance to work for national newspapers, including The Sun, The Sunday Times, The , Daily Mail, Daily and Sunday Express and .Sarah Jones MP and the Croydon BME Forum launched the initiative to help young people gain the experience and networks necessary to secure highly competitive journalism jobs.The Journey to Journalism programme aims to increase ersity within the  per cent white profession, as research has found just . per cent of British journalists are Muslim and only . per cent are black.Applicants must write a letter and a -word article on kne crime to submit by nd December.Leading BAME journalists Fatima Manji and Stephen Bush will judge applications.A recent survey of more than one million young people identied ending kne crime as their number one concern.It is also one of Jones’ key priorities as Chair of the All Party Parliamentary Group on Kne Crime.The MP for Croydon Central challenged several senior news editors to do more about potential unconscious bias in newspapers’ portrayal of BAME iniduals — due to the industry’s lack of ersity.Research has found that successful applicants are usually white, male, and from privileged backgrounds.Jones argued that this creates a “barrier to entry” for aspiring journalists who do not have personal connections to the industry.Just  per cent of journalists come from working-class backgrounds.Jones said: “Earlier this year I challenged newspaper editors over unconscious bias in their papers given the lack of BAME journalists.“They all expressed a desire to increase ersity, and I’m glad they have agreed to offer this exciting opportunity to young people in Croydon.“Requirements for work experience are too often a barrier to entry in jobs like journalism for those who aren’t lucky enough to have family connections. I’m looking forward to working with the Croydon BME Forum and a team of top journalists to uncover the huge potential among Croydon’s young people.”Andrew Brown, Chief Executive of the Croydon BME Forum, said: “This journalism programme gives talented, BAME students the chance to enter an industry that shapes the way people perceive the world – and perhaps even challenge those established views.That’s powerful and it is that process of empowerment and giving a voice to people that embodies what the Croydon BME Forum is all about.”To apply, click hereOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit bbc fact chuckers
story: We have no choice. In , we expect our national broadcaster to reflect all our opinions even-handedly.We don’t want the BBC to tell us that one side is right and the other wrong, or what we should believe, or which opinions are “true” and which are “”.But that is what the BBC has started to do, at least on the subject of Brexit.The BBC tried to be reasonably balanced during the referendum campaign, but it was so upset by the outcome that it has abandoned any attempt at impartiality and become grotesquely one-sided.The views of Remainers are not just over-represented, they are rarely challenged. And scare stories about Brexit which are either exaggerated or completely imaginary are presented as fact.I decided to compile a list of myths about Brexit — particularly scare stories about what will happen when we leave the Customs Union orwe leave Europe without a deal.Then I compared them with the facts. Although the pamphlet did not mention the BBC, most of the myths were things we hear daily on its programmes.The BBC rose to the bait and invited me into the Today programme on Radio  yesterday to be grilled by John Humphrys, its star interviewer. It was a fair enough interview. He challenged my arguments but I was able to refute his claims point by point.However, they then brought on a chap called Chris Morris, described as the BBC “reality checker”, who was invited to rebut my document. But all he did was oppose my facts with the opinions of people with whom he agreed.He systematically argued the Remain case and defended their Project Fear scare stories. The one thing he did not do was bring in any new facts. My central claim was thatwe leave the EU Customs Union but have a free trade agreement with the European Union, our businesses have little to fear.The main dference will be that traders will have to send in a customs declaration detailing the goods they are buying from or selling to Europe.That is a nuisance which we should try to simply as much as possible.But allegations that “this will be hugely costly, cause y delays, disrupt supply chains and undermine economic growth” are imaginary or exaggerated.“Fact checker” Morris said the majority of trade experts and freight companies to whom he had spoken robustly disagreed with me. This is an opinion, not a fact.Surely,trading in a free trade area — like that which exists between Switzerland and the EU or between Canada and the US — is so intolerable, the people there would be calling for a customs union.But they aren’t. I prefer their practical experience to the speculation of Mr Morris’s contacts.I also quoted a report by the CLECAT organisation, which covers , companies handling  per cent of the freight and customs in Europe, who said: “All the ingredients to ensure a smooth exit process of the UK from the EU, and which allow almost frictionless trade after the exit, are already available.”Why should a BBC fact checker’s unnamed contacts count for more than their considered view He then claimed there are no checks at the border at present. I go across to my house in France frequently and see the checks — for drugs, illegal immigrants, alcohol, cigarettes.And companies have to report all their cross-border trade separately on their VAT s and provide statistical s to Brussels.Then Mr Morris claimed there would be more checks by our customs officers at Dover, resulting in delays and disruption. That is nonsense.The Head of Customs and Revenue has said it only stops and searches lorries at present where it has intelligence information about drugs, illegal immigrants, and goods such as tobacco and alcohol, upon which excise duty is paid.It does not expect any of these risks to become more frequent. So it will not need to search any more vehicles.As I was still in the studio, I was able to rebut his pathetic attempts to rebut my facts. Normally he gets a clear run.But what is intolerable is that he almost never tries to rebut arguments by those trying to overturn the referendum result.I asked him afterwards to name a single Remainer whose case he had attempted to dissect. When he replied that there were “lots”, I said it should be easy to name one and, after repeated challenges, he named Jeremy Corbyn.The idea that Mr Corbyn — a man who has voted more often against European membership than any other MP and went on holiday during the referendum — is a Remainer could only be taken for reality by a BBC reality checker.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britains first cloned dog gives birth
story: Minnie Winnie, a dachshund conceived in a test tube in , had two male pups delivered by emergency caesarean section.Her owner, Rebecca Bourne, , said she decided to breed from Minnie Winnie after the clone’s mother, Winnie, died last year.She said: “I couldn’t be more thrilled. They are just gorgeous and Minnie Winnie is so pleased with them. It’s a dream come true to continue Winnie’s legacy.“It’s funny, because Minnie Winnie was cloned, the pups are closer to being Winnie’s sons than her grandsons. They’re still effectively a little piece of her which I love.”Winnie was cloned after Rebecca won a £, competition to have her pet reproduced.Minnie Winnie was conceived in a laboratory in Seoul, South Korea.She was born on March , , to a surrogate mother before being flown to Britain to join Winnie at Rebecca’s home in Battersea, South London.But Winnie died aged  after being hit by a car.Rebecca said: “When we lost Winnie in May last year, it was literally the worst day of my le.”However, it spurred her to breed from her pet’s cloned offspring.Minnie Winnie became pregnant earlier this year but reabsorbed the litter, a natural and common occurrence which disappoints breeders.Then on November  she had her two pups, fathered by a seven-year-old dachshund named Otto.Rebecca said: “There was one big one and one little one. The big one was blocking the way out into the world so they had to be delivered by emergency C section to ensure the safety of both Minnie Winnie and the pups.“It was a pretty stressful time but they were in very good hands. Minnie Winnie has taken to motherhood like a duck to water, she adores her pups and is a very attentive mummy.“The pups are thriving and we all adore them.”Author Rebecca has yet to name the pups officially although the vet called the bigger one Wally and the smaller one Willy.Rebecca has written a children’s book, The Wilbies Go To The Moon, documenting the adventures of her son Wilbur, three, with Minnie Winnie and Winnie.MINNIE Winnie was created by scientists who took a skin sample from her mother, Winnie.It was stored in liquid nitrogen and flown to South Korea.The team took an egg from another female dog and removed the nucleus, which holds the genetic material. Winnie’s DNA was placed into the egg which was given electric shocks to trigger cell ision.The egg was then implanted into a surrogate. title: dup is not bluffing backstop
story: They want the Irish “backstop”, which weakens the Britain Northern Ireland union, binned. Or they’ll collapse the Tory Government their votes prop up.To the DUP the sanctity of the union is everything — far more fundamental even than keeping Corbyn, a notorious supporter of the IRA, and a united Ireland, out of Downing Street. Mrs May’s deal is an immediate threat.Corbyn can be fought later,he ever takes power. The Sun doesn’t see the DUP coming round. The PM must fix the backstop.No, the EU won’t play ball. But the deal is in disarray anyhow, here and in Brussels. Spain, France and Germany want it rewritten to punish us further. Others want more fishing rights. Our MPs won’t back it as it is, let alone an even harder version.But, that aside, Mrs May cannot govern at all without the DUP. And she must not try just to tough this out.She and Michel Barnier need solutions.WILL the Tories ever put the public health busybodies back in their box The fizzy drinks tax was just the start. As The Sun always predicted, they’re now after everything  . . . yoghurts, cereals, takeaways, you name it.They claim customers want the food industry to cut sugar — and that the Government must use “fiscal levers”needed to enforce it. That’s a weasel phrase meaning “new taxes consumers will end up paying”.Yes, obesity is a problem. story: The short clips, posted to Instagram, show a Chinese woman dressed in new season outfits from the Italian fashion house attempting to eat pizza with chopsticks.The videos are a part of the firms new DG Loves China campaign promoting a runway show in Shanghai on November .The ad, posted to the brand’s Instagram account, comes in three parts, with all three showing the same woman attempting to eat a pizza, a Sicilian cannoli and a large bowl of spaghetti.The captions on the posts said: “Welcome to Episode  with Dolce  Gabbana’s ‘Eating with Chopsticks’.“First up today is how to use this stick shaped cutlery to eat your GREAT traditional Pizza Margherita.”The campaign was also posted to the Chinese social media  Weibo where it was deleted less than  hours after it was uploaded.On Weibo, Boycott Dolce has now been discussed more than , times.Some users have asked that an apology to be issued - in both Chinese and English.Instagram users have also slammed the brand with the majority of comments underneath the videos asking for immediate removal of the campaign.One person wrote: “Crass. Racist. Condescending.”Chloxu said: “This is absolutely unacceptable! It has been three days and the content is not taken down.Vvvvlu said: “Dolce  Gabbana are racist and did not bother to learn the first thing about their Chinese customers. This ad is an insult to my culture.”Shirleymh wrote: “Full of stereotype, irony and discrimination.”The Italian designers - Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana - are no strangers to controversy and have had bust-ups with A-listers including Elton John and Selena Gomez in the past.Elton called for a boycott of the -year-old fashion brand after Dolce labelled children born through IVF “synthetic”.The singer and songwriter, , who has two children with his husband, David Furnish, angrily responded to the designer for criticising same-sex families and the use of fertility treatment.In an Instagram post, John said: “How dare you refer to my beautul children as ‘synthetic’.“And shame on you for wagging your judgemental little fingers at IVF – a miracle that has allowed legions of loving people, both straight and gay, to fulfil their dream of having children.“Your archaic thinking is out of step with the times, just like your fashions. I shall never wear Dolce and Gabbana ever again. #BoycottDolceGabbana.”The incident regarding Selena Gomez in June  saw -year-old Gabbana comment underneath a collage of photos of Gomez: “She’s so ugly!!!”In a post uploaded to his Instagram story but since deleted, the Italian designer mocked Gomez fans who requested he apologise to her with a screenshot where he said: “My name is Selena!!! #saysorrytome” with a caption of laughing emojis.The Asia Pacic region makes up around  per cent of DG sales.

title: mark carney backs theresa may withdrawal plans
story: In a hearing with MPs on the Treasury Select Committee, Mr Carney said: “We have emphasised from the start the importance of having some transition between the current arrangements and the ultimate arrangements.“So we welcome the transition arrangements in the withdrawal agreement... and take note of the possibility of extending that transition period.”The transition period starts on March  and is due to end on December , . Carney highlighted that a lack of a transition would deliver a “large negative shock” to the British economy – akin to the s oil shock.A no-deal scenario - seen as the “worse outcome” by the Bank - was not one in which the central bank could ride to the economy’s rescue with lower interest rates, MPs heard.Michael Saunders, one external member of the Monetary Policy Committee, said: “If you have queues at Dover, the answer to the UK economy is not lower interest rates.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dup strike theresa may budget vote
story: The Ulster unionists’ ten MPs abstained in votes on the Finance Bill for the second night in a row.Their refusal to back the Government on the all-important money legislation is a clear breach of the confidence and supply agreement that cost taxpayers £billion.But senior DUP sources last night told The Sun the party would continue to stay away from Commons votes until Mrs May agrees to rip up her controversial Irish backstop.The senior DUP figure said: “I don’t think we’ll see much Government legislation tabled next week, as they know what we’ll do now.“They are breaking the agreement, not us. They are nor delivering on our joint priorities - which is the Union.”The demand comes as the PM heads out to Brussels this afternoon to take personal charge of negotiations ahead of Sunday’s summit of EU leaders to sign off the deal.During a  minute meeting with EU Commission boos Jean-Claude Juncker, Mrs May will spell out what she still wants to see in the deal’s political declaration of future hopes for a trade deal.The Cabinet yesterday backed Theresa May to “win a game of two halves” and turn around bitter Tory and DUP opposition to her orce deal by winning a promise of a good trade deal from the EU in the future.Attorney General Geoffrey Cox presented the PM’s top table with the football analogy, adding: “I am confident we can win it back in the second half”.Environment Secretary Michael Gove added: “It’s a European Cup tie - a home fixture and then an away fixture”.But the DUP also insist she must tell Mr Juncker she is to abandon the controversial Irish backstop agreed last week that places Northern Ireland under a dferent set of EU rules to the rest of the UK.The DUP’s deputy leader Nigel Dodds said: “It is time for the Prime Minister to work for a better deal.“The only option is to look beyond this Withdrawal Agreement.“A stubborn determination by the PM to pursue a binary choice of this deal or no deal is not in the country’s interests.”Mrs May’s minority administration relies on the DUP’s ten MPs to give her a majority in the Commons.If they abstain on votes, it reduces her majority to just three andthey vote against the Government the Tories will be defeated.Chancellor Philip Hammond as well as Brexit rebel Boris Johnson are both expected to speak at the DUP’s annual conference this weekend to try to court the pro-British party for their opposing causes.But when asked who had the best ideas for Brexit a bleak “None” was the highest response to a list of MPs, with  per cent of people choosing that option.Tory Jacob Rees-Mogg and ex-Ukip boss Nigel Farage had eight per cent and Theresa May five per cent, said OnePoll’s survey.But the DUP’s Sammy Wilson told ministers that they will not back down with more bribes, adding: “We fought through a terrorist campaign - we had , people killed in Northern Ireland to remain in the United Kingdom.“If you think we’re going to be bought off by a few baubles in order to allow this deal to go through we won’t be”.Sources claim Downing Street chief of staff Gavin Barwell told Cabinet Ministers last week the Government was “one nil” down given concessions in the Withdrawal Agreement.When told, Eurosceptic Iain Duncan Smith joked: “I’d say they’re three nil down, against Barcelona and they’ve had a player sent off.”Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom also professed her loyalty to Mrs May yesterday during Cabinet after last week’s resignations, despite being the ringleader of the ‘Pizza Club’of plotters.Brexiteer Ms Leadsom opened her speech to the table by saying: “Prime Minister, I don’t even like pizza”.Last night the Government took the extraordinary step of accepting opposition amendments on the Finance Bill, which is the legislation that passes the Budget.Government whips feared a humiliating loss on the votes - which were Labour and SNP demands for more action on tax evasion and tax avoidance - in the wake of the DUP’s decision not to back the Government in the crucial votes.It raised even further questions about Mrs May’s ability to govern a majority in the Commons.A Labour source said: “The Government in all effect has given up on government. Governments simply do not accept amendments to the Finance Bill. They’ve been forced to accept amendments. It’s extraordinary.“Fundamentally when a government can’t pass Budgets, they’re not in power.This is a pretty signicant moment.”Former Tory leader Lord Howard last night tore apart Mrs Mays plans to avoid a hard border in Ireland.He questioned how the proposed backstop plan would mean taking back control.He said: Under Article  the United Kingdom has a unilateral, untrammelled right to leave the European Union.Under the backstop provisions of the withdrawal agreement, the United Kingdom can only leave with the consent of the European Union.How can that be described as taking back control Brexit Minister Lord Callanan replied: There are mechanisms to bring the backstop to an end. But he is right to say they are mechanisms that would need to be mutually agreed.I do understand the point he is making.They want the Irish “backstop”, which weakens the Britain Northern Ireland union, binned. Or they’ll collapse the Tory Government their votes prop up.To the DUP the sanctity of the union is everything — far more fundamental even than keeping Corbyn, a notorious supporter of the IRA, and a united Ireland, out of Downing Street. Mrs May’s deal is an immediate threat. Corbyn can be fought later,he ever takes power.The Sun doesn’t see the DUP coming round. The PM must fix the backstop.No, the EU won’t play ball. But the deal is in disarray anyhow, here and in Brussels. Spain, France and Germany want it rewritten to punish us further.Others want more fishing rights.Our MPs won’t back it as it is, let alone an even harder version.But, that aside, Mrs May cannot govern at all without the DUP. And she must not try just to tough this out.She and Michel Barnier need solutions.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit talks juncker
story: The Prime Minister will jet to Brussels for afternoon tea with Jean Claude Juncker later today to secure more wins on our future relationship with the EU to try and appease her warring party.Sources close to the chief whip said Mrs May had to come back with something new to give to unhappy Tories - or her hard-won agreement would get voted down within days.A Tory source said: The chief whips view is that fear of No Deal will not be enough to win this one.The numbers are terrible and he needs something sufficiently dferent from what people currently think they are voting for in order to get this through.But new DWP boss Amber Rudd said today that Nos strategy of pressuring MPs to vote for the deal because of the fear of nothing at all wouldnt work.In remarkable comments this morning she insisted that there was no majority in Parliament for No Deal and believed thatMPs voted down the deal, Parliament would stop us leaving with nothing at all in place.I dont accept that at all, she said.Ms Rudd, who took over from Esther McVey last week, told Radio  that MPs should take a fresh look at the deal once Mrs May comes back with it later.This is the cake, its been baked, the Prime Minister will bring it back... perhaps that will remind colleagues that there is still a negotiation going on.However, she also warned that Mrs May might not be able to finish the changes she wants today, and it wont be able to be signed off by Sundays summit with EU leaders.Tory MP Damian Collins this morning also called for an election or a second referendumParliament voted down the deal - which would throw Brexit into further chaos.The Prime Minister is in a stronger position as she jets off today after a coup against her failed to materialise, and not enough letters came in to force a vote of no confidence in her.It is believed that the Brexiteer rebels are still a few letters short of the  needed, and yesterday Jacob Rees-Mogg admitted it had all gone a bit Dads Army - and warned a coup against her could come next month instead.And Cabinet ministers could get behind a new technological solution to solve the Irish border issue - as first revealed by The Sun this week.Mrs May told her ministers yesterday the country could avoid having to use the controversial Irish border backstop after Brexit because of a new plan to avoid a hard border with alternative arrangements of technical solutions away from the border.But the Prime Minister faces a fresh Brexit headache when she gets there as grumbling EU nations are set to try and force Britain into taking even MORE concessions before a deal is sealed.Several nations including want us to back down over fishing rights and Gibraltar.Spain even said they could BLOCK the Brexit dealGibraltar is included in a future trade deal.Meanwhile France wants “side declarations” on fishing and following EU rules to be included in the trade blueprint to show Britain the cost of leaving.Paris is insisting on the clauses, including one demanding access to UK waters and another on tough Level Playing Field provisions, despite Mr Barnier warning they could torpedo the deal.Today Ex-Brexit boss Dominic Raab today demanded we threaten to walk away with our £billion to force the EU into act.Writing in thetoday he blasted: This is a historic struggle for the heart and soul of our country - between those who believe that managed decline is all we have left, and those of us who believe that this countrys best days lie ahead.Buried beneath the rafts of technical detail, it is a struggle between hope and fear.The current document on our future partnership with the EU is just seven pages long, but Cabinet ministers were this week shown a -page draft which will be discussed between Mrs May and Mr Juncker today.The more flesh we can put on the bones, the better. story: A year later Nancy Astor was to become the first sitting female MP.Lady Astor won a bi-election in Plymouth Sutton, where she remained as MP until . title: web creator sir tim berners lee i see a revolution starting right now
story: The awakening for him, as for so many people, came in , with the twin shocks of Brexit and the election of Donald Trump."What happened there was a tipping point," he says.He knew that social media could be used to manipulate people, but for the first time he saw it operating at massive scale."I thought that my responsibility as a web user was to go and find the stuff which I appreciated, which I trusted, but now I think that everyone involved in the web realises the problem is that other people are reading stuff which is complete garbage and theyre believing it, and they vote."He mentions voting. story: News#IStandWithHarry: Jeremy Corbyn leads support for stricken Harry Leslie SmithThe -year-old WWII veteran and campaigner is critically ill in hospital after a fall in Canada, his son John confirmed on TwitterShareCommentsByNatalie EvansUS Editor Mikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video harry-leslie-smith-moves-audience-,customFields:,suggestedData:,gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn led thousands of well-wishers in support of campaigner Harry Leslie Smith who is critically ill after a fall. The -year-old WWII veteran is in hospital in Canada after his accident while visiting his son John. Tweeting from his fathers official account, John said Harry had low blood pressure and “drts in and out of consciousness, but it breathing well with oxygen.” Later tweets indicated that his father may be suffering from pneumonia and is still critical but not acutely.  He added: I told Harry before he fell into a deep sleep about the concern rippling across Twitter for him and he said to me, tell them, I love each of them so much. Fears grew for the Labour Party activist after his son revealed he had requested a DNR . But Harrys inimitable determination shone through as John confirmed his father had told the doctor: I can assure you, I am not ready to die because I have too much work to do. The hashtag #IStandWithHarry trended on Twitter as thousands of well-wishers sent their support to the stricken hero. Labour leader Mr Corbyn led the tributes to Harry, tweeting: Very sorry to hear this. Please pass on my best to Harry. We need him to get well soon as the National Health Service, and our movement, needs him. War hero Harry shot to fame with a moving speech to Labour Party conference in . He stole the show, moving delegates to tears during a debate on the NHS and social care. Hospitals, doctors and medicine were for the privileged few, because they were run by profit, he told the hall. My memories stretch back almost a hundred years, andI close my eyes, I can smell the poverty that oozes from the dusty tenement streets of my boyhood.  The Barnsley-born miner’s son has since become a tireless campaigner against poverty, for the rights of refugees and workers and for keeping the NHS in public hands. Harry joined the RAF at , serving as a pilot in World War II, lived through the Great Depression and lost his sister Marion to tuberculosis when she was just  years old because his family couldn’t afford a doctor. Last year, he celebrated winning a battle with pneumonia, telling the Mirror he would have died without the NHS.  He said: “I know were it not for the NHS my le would have ended a long time ago because I come from an endless ancestry of hard-working folk whose labour never paid enough to afford a pleasant le. “The working class only came to good fortune when a Labour government was elected in .”

title: un blasts amber rudd brands
story: NewsUN blasts Amber Rudd as she brands Universal Credit tremendous force for goodThe new Work and Pensions Secretary has hailed the six-in-one benefit and dismissed a critical UN report - but its author accuses her of "missing the point"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV NewsIn her first interview since taking the job today, the Work and Pensions Secretary hailed the benefit as a tremendous force for good "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA United Nations expert has blasted Amber Rudd after the Tory welfare chief dug in her heels to defend the disastrous rollout of Universal Credit. In her first interview since taking the job today, the Work and Pensions Secretary hailed the benefit as a tremendous force for good.She also repeated her criticism of a very political report that savaged welfare cuts by the UN special rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights.That UN expert, Philip Alston, found punitive, mean-spirited and often callous welfare cuts had inflicted great misery on the British people. Last night he hit back at Ms Rudd, saying she had missed the point.  Mr Alston told : Alston, the UN special rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights, told the : “I think that dismissing a report that is full of statistics and first-hand testimony on the grounds that the minister didn’t appreciate the tone of the report rather misses the point. I remain hopeful that Amber Rudd might actually take some of the steps needed to address the worst aspects of the existing approach. Ms Rudd first criticised the UN report in her first appearance as Work and Pensions Secretary in the House of Commons. Today she added it was implying it was an effort to make some sort of social engineering which is detrimental to people. She promised to look at particular elements raised in the report. But despite Tory George Osborne slashing billions from benefits she claimed: What I resent about his approach is the motives he attributes to us. The motives are wrong.  Ms Rudd admitted there had been problems with Universal Credit including soaring use of food banks adding: I’m looking at what we can do to get cash into people’s hands earlier. The Tory also hinted at a shake-up to the policy of paying people monthly, saying: I think that’s something I should look at and I will.But she did not commit to halt the rollout of the benefit, which some campaigners now say needs to be scrapped.She said UC is more generous than the old system, telling the BBC: This is going to be dferent and better.

title: christmas traditions like pudding pennies
story: NewsChristmas traditions like pudding pennies, carol singing and trees are dying outChristmas used to be a time for tipping the paperboy or binman, supping on eggnogg and watching a James Bond film - but fewer people are joining in than everShareCommentsByGrant Bailey:,  NOV NewsA third of people wont put up a Christmas tree "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMuch-loved Christmas traditions such as eggnog, pennies in the pudding and carol singing are now practically a thing of past, it has emerged. Tipping the paperboy and binmen and even watching a James Bond film on December th are no longer part of the festive routine. Researchers who carried out a detailed study found time and financial pressures are to blame along with a fear of not wanting to give the impression of being old fashioned. Overall more than half the , adults who took part expressed a belief that old traditions are falling by the wayside.  The stats show just a third of Brits will hang a wreath on their door this year, and only  per cent will put up a Christmas tree. Amazingly, one in four will NOT enjoy a Christmas dinner with all the trimmings this year. In fact, only seven in  are planning a traditional giving and receiving of gts. British Corner Shop – who export products to Brits around the world – carried out the in-depth research. A spokeswoman said: “Our research found there are lots of classic traditions that appear to be falling by the wayside.  “In fact, what we consider to be ‘traditional’ Christmas customs may no longer have a place at the Christmas of the future. “However, where old traditions die off, new ones are coming up to take their place – and there are still lots of old traditions that are as popular as ever.” It also emerged one tenth of festive Brits are set to watch a James Bond film on television – often a staple part of a long Christmas afternoon slumped in front of the TV. And just one in seven plan to have a nativity scene taking pride of place in their front room. Fewer than one in  plan to do Christmas carolling this season, and only five per cent will take part in Christingle. Nearly eight in  adults think that people have fewer interactions with friends and neighbours as a result of traditional Christmas activities decline.  And the majority of Brits believe that as years go by, Christmas gets less special, with the Christmas spirit peaking at age , then petering out. Of more modern traditions that have come to prominence in recent years, a fth of Brits now take part in a ‘Secret Santa’. And three in  love wearing novelty Christmas jumpers, with a further one in five visiting German Christmas markets in the run-up to the big day. A huge  per cent of respondents believe Christmas seems to start earlier and earlier every year, with eight in  Brits wishing it would revert to its old values. The study also uncovered the key dferences in how younger and older Brits will choose to celebrate Christmas this year. While the Christmas dinner remains the focal point for the day, and the festive event Brits cannot do without regardless of age, there were some key dferences.  Brits aged  to  are more likely to prioritise putting up a Christmas tree to mark the occasion. They are also more inclined to watch a Christmas film, open an advent calendar in the run up to the big day and listen to Christmas songs, according to the OnePoll study. Brits over the age of  prefer to celebrate by eating mince pies, hanging a wreath on their door and going for a post-dinner walk to burn off some calories. British Corner Shop’s spokeswoman added: “Young or old, some things are so quintessentially Christmas we couldn’t be without them. “While the entirety of the Christmas season is made up of a patchwork of traditions, nothing is more vital to the experience than friends and family gathering around the table for the most indulgent supper of the year.” Christmas traditions on the wane - and percentage of nation who WILL adopt them this year- Send a letter to Father Christmas through the fire - %- Christingle - %- Drink eggnog - %- Put a sixpence or penny in a Christmas pudding - %- Going out to sing Christmas Carols - %- Decorate a gingerbread house - %- Donate a shoebox to charity- %- Watch a James Bond film - %- Set fire to the Christmas pudding - %- Go to the Christmas pantomime - %- Hang mistletoe - %- Give a tip to your postman or binman - %- Have a nativity scene - %- Put holly and ivy up - %- Leave a mince pie and carrots out for Santa and his reindeer - %- Have a real Christmas tree - %- Drink mulled wine - %- Watch The Queens Speech - %- Put a stocking out - %- Go for a post-Christmas dinner walk - %

title: kids not ready lose mummy
story: NewsKids not ready to lose mummy after she was diagnosed with cancer while pregnantLeanne Barret, , from Derby, was diagnosed with lung cancer while pregnant and her family are raising money for le-prolonging treatmentShareCommentsByElaine McCahillNathan Standley:,  NOV NewsA womans children arent ready to lose their mummy after she was diagnosed with lung cancer while pregnant "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young dad told has told of how his young children arent ready to lose their mummy after his we was diagnosed with cancer while pregnant. Jamie Barretts we Leanne was diagnosed with stage four lung cancer in October after a growth the size of a pea grew into a five-centimetre mass on her left lung. Leanne, , gave birth to their baby boy  weeks prematurely after doctors decided the growth hormones caused by her pregnancy were stopping her from responding to treatment. The couple are now raising funds for le-prolonging treatment as Jamie, , said: Im not ready to lose my we and my kids arent ready to lose their mummy.  After her diagnosis, Leanne decided to continue with the pregnancy and endured a series of agonising investigative procedures throughout, reports Derbyshire Live.Leanne had been given the option of an abortion but decided against it as she had bonded with her unborn child, Jamie said.The couple were later told they were having a baby boy after losing his unborn twin before the -week scan. But doctors were forced to deliver the baby early as Leanne needed further treatment. Their baby boy, Beau Hudson Barrett, was born via Caesarean section atThe Royal Derby Hospital on November , weighing just lb oz. The couple are also parents to daughter India-Lily.Beau remains in neo-natal intensive care but his dad Jamie says he is coping well. He said: Hes doing well, hes fighting and hes improved day by day. The team down there have been absolutely brilliant.   Jamie, from Rolleston, who is thecaptain of Gresley FC, said of his daughter: Were trying to keep her away from all this. She knows that her mummys been poorly but she thinks that its just to do with the pregnancy. Jamie and Leanne have been together for  years and Leanne enjoyed a happy, healthy and active pregnancy in  when their first child, India-Lily, was born. The couple were married in , but shortly afterwards Jamie said Leanne developed what looked like a pimple on her nose which they got checked once it continued to grow. Doctors said this was likely a symptom of an auto-immune disease called Sarcoidosis and sent her for aseries of CT scans and X-rays. Further scans on her chest showed that Leanne had a mass of enlarged lymphnodes in her chest, which later tests showed were benign. But in July , Leanne began to complain of having chest pains and trouble breathing, which is when doctors found the five-centimetre mass on her lung. After visiting a specialist lung doctor at the Nuffield Health Centre in Derby, Leanne was diagnosed with stage four lung cancer. Doctors had already offered aiety of biopsy options to try to get to the bottom of what caused the growth, but some of these could have threatened her pregnancy and she was determined to give her baby the best possible chance. She even underwent painful investigative procedures, including chest drains and blood thinning injections, with minimal pain relief to minimise the effect on her unborn baby.  But since the birth of her son, Leannes cancer has progressed and spread rapidly to her liver, bones and brain. Jamie said Leanne had always beenvery active, enjoying running, swimming and gym classes, and had never smoked. He said: Id just say to everyone go and get checked out and be persistent, always get asecond opinion. I know not everyone has the option of private healthcare but I dread to think where we would be now without having had that second opinion. You always think its never going to happen to you, but no-one should be naive enough to think that. Jamie said he had been told that Leannes is the first case in the region where the cancer is known to have spread so quickly.He decided to start a JustGiving page not just to raise money for her treatment, but to raise awareness of her case and hopefully find someone who might be able to help.He said: It was something that I considered long and hard. We both had hard-working jobs and we lived a comfortable le, but now were not working and we need that extra treatment and to spread awareness of her story. Hopefully there is someone  out there who might be able to help us. Jamie, who is the captain and holder of the record number of appearances for Gresley FC, said he has a number of contacts in the football community and was hoping to get the page shared by some high profile names. But even he did not expect the overwhelming response that they got.   In less than  hours, they had smashed through their initial pound, target and by Tuesday they were heading rapidly towards a revised target of pound,, with more than,people having contributed. We cant thank people enough, he said. People have been incredible. Theres a lot of people supporting us and everyones been so generous. The money is set to go towards funding direct specialist treatment and other alternative homeopathic treatments to prolong Leannes le. Jamie said: Weve started some new treatment now which will keep her comfortable. Yes we want to prolong her le but ultimately we want to defy the odds, were praying for her every day and were remaining positive that she can and will beat this. Leanne has been simply overwhelmed by the well wishes, messages of support, flowers and gts that shes received. What shed love more than anything  in this world is to see her babies grow up and to be able to say that shes beating cancer.Anyone hoping to donate can do so on the JustGiving page.

story: NewsMum of Britains biggest family with  kids reveals incredible daily routineSue and Noel Radford welcomed baby Bonnie earlier this month, adding to their huge brood in Morecambe, LancashireShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video britains-largest-family-reveals-daily-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother-of- has revealed her hectic daily routine - which includes nine loads of washing EVERY DAY. Noel, , spoke about their newest arrival in a video created by Zanussi. He said: Just because weve got , that doesnt change our feelings towards having a new baby at all. But, despite their love of having children, Noel said they have decided to stop at  - and will not have any more children. Sue said: “We’ve both decided we don’t want any more. title: mum watching santa parade told
story: NewsMum watching Santa parade told child with autism cant use disabled viewing areaThe argument over where a seven-year-old girl could stand led to a massive row between parents at Princes Quay shopping centre in Hull, East YorkshireShareCommentsByJoanna LovellBradley Jolly:,  NOV NewsThe Santa Parade made its way through Hull on the weekend "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum watching a Santa parade was sickened after she was told her daughter with autism had no right to use the disabled . Marta, , told the woman not all disabilities are visible as they waited for Father Christmas to arrive at Princes Quay shopping centre in Hull, East Yorks., on the weekend.A dad had to calm the warring women, Hull Daily Mail says.Marta said: My daughter has autism and I put myself in the disabled area. I just found the area by coincidence. I was looking for a place and then saw the area and I thought why not   My daughter is OK with crowded places most of the time, but she rocks a lot to the sides and sometimes disturbs people by doing that, so I just thought lets go in there. When the woman saw me going in the area she said you cant be there, thats for disabled people. So I said not all disabilities are visible and she said Its not for prams. She thought I was there because I had a pram with me. I said Look, my eldest one has autism, then she said get out of my face. I said excuse me, how can you be so disrespectful  So she went shut up, be quiet, and it went on and on an on.  I told her things like you cant judge people so easily, you are disrespectful, its ridiculous all this. She was just telling me to shut up then saying to her kids this woman is being silly. It just made me mad she was telling me to shut up. At least once seeing her mistake she could have apologised. The argument upset other children around the mums.
