title: neil-oliver-on-his-british-isles-in-100-places-tour-and-why-nicola-sturgeon-is-the-kirk-elder
story: I wonder how Oliver has achieved this longevity in a business that dumps presenters like plastic in the sea  Andtherersquos a sense that Churchillrsquos borrowed quote "Those who fail to learn from history are condemned to repeat it" rings as true as a church bell, surely the opposite should apply  Given Oliver knows an awful lot about history and archaeology, could TV survival be down to the fact hersquos learned what not to do We meet at the Stirling Smith Art Gallery and Museum, near where he lives with his we and three children. Oliver looks way younger than  years on this planet would suggest, and is relaxed, yet on the clock, given one of his brood has to picked up from school in an hour.He certainly has the energy to undertake a tour of the great theatre halls of the land with his new show, telling of the British Isles in  Places, Glasgow this week which expands upon the detail in his new book of the same title. But his is all new to him  ldquoIrsquove spoken in public before, at literary festivals, but not night after night, he says. ldquoI only get a couple of days off during the months and itrsquos quite intense and nerve wracking. Having said that, itrsquos a fascinating and very dferent way of seeing a country. And it makes you question the notion of what a country is. Once you interrogate this notion you realise the audience in the North East [of England], for example, is a very dferent tribe from those in the South."You get this throughout Scotland as well. The iety of what you find leaves you confused. At times you donrsquot know where you are.But there is a commonality, I ask. Arent we all in the same boat ndash one which seems to be sinking  He doesnrsquot think so. ldquoWersquove been through everything, from invasion to natural disaster to famine to religious fundamentalism, he says. ldquoWersquove been through civil war, wars of independence, the industrial revolution, two world wars. All of this has unfolded in the same tapestry. This is just a period in history. In a  years there will be dferent issues and a dferent set of politics.Thatrsquos a comfort. Sort of. But meantime, what do we do about Brexit, Neil  ldquoI donrsquot want to deal in that, he says, placing his coffee cup down with a slightly emphatic clump, suggesting hersquos learned to avoid controversy. ldquoIrsquom careful not to offer an opinion on any of that. My tour aim is to put an arm around the shoulder of someone I care about, which is this archipelago. Itrsquos a love letter to the British Isles, a spectacular place which has looked after me, and now itrsquos my turn to look after him ndash or her.He offers a thought: ldquoThe motto of the Isle of Man, lsquoWhichever way you throw me I will standrsquo, the three legged symbol, I think thatrsquos a great motto for people to live by.Thatrsquos easy to say, but wersquore facing confusion, polarisation of politics, right-wing extremism. You must be afraid of the isions politics has produced and the invective that comes with it  It seems everyone wants to be angry.ldquoIrsquom sick of politics, he admits. ldquoIrsquom completely disenchanted with all of it. Politicians lack so much knowledge. If Irsquom honest, I donrsquot think therersquos a politician out there worth listening to, of any creed or colour. I donrsquot have any truck with any of them. Irsquom just looking away at the moment while they do what they do, which is self-aggrandizing and performing their Punch and Judy nonsense. I cannot be bothered with it.He adds: ldquoI was in that arena vaguely for a while on account of a few opinions I was invited to give.He certainly was. Oliver incurred the wrath of the Nationalists back in  when he declared independence for Scotland a "dead dog."But does he now regret becoming involved in the independence debate He pauses for thought. ldquoNo, I think itrsquos important to say what you think is true. But I donrsquot like the atmosphere at the moment whereby you canrsquot say what you think. If you are not pleasing the social media mob you are silenced or destroyed. I was asked some questions and I gave an honest answer.Oliver rejects the offer of half a sconeand instead sips at his coffee cup. ldquoHow it really started for me was when I was being interviewed for Bannockburn  [his TV show] and a journalist asked me about the referendum. ldquoI remember saying, lsquoA referendum is like going shopping for food when yoursquore hungry.rsquo You donrsquot want to be making snap decisions.Because you come away with a packet of Hobnobs and a jar of Nutella  ldquoExactly. I donrsquot think we should have referendums to decide which side of the road we should drive on, never mind kicking the ball back to the general population to determine a nationrsquos destiny. Thatrsquos why we have political democracy, whereby we employ hundreds of people to read tedious paperwork, shout and bawl at each other in a room for as long as it takes. Thatrsquos why these -odd people have a job.He becomes more animated. ldquoReferendums are a bad idea. After the Scottish referendum there were immediate cries for another one. lsquoThat disnae countrsquo. Now therersquos been Europe. And that was seen to be wrong. And so you claim for another one. What do you do  Go for best of three  Or best of five Oliver smiles. ldquoIrsquove never been a card-carrying member of a political party. I used to scoff at university friends who were. In the same way I couldnrsquot understand why anyone would get excited about football. Irsquom not minded that way.Yet, but he is minded to recognise how politics overlaps into culture and issues of identity, which he loves to wax lyrical about on his TV shows. But there are those who donrsquot countenance his passion for explaining the likes of Iona and the coming of Christianity. Some, such as Professor Tom Devine, see Oliver as an irritant.The historian once attacked the fact Oliver had been asked to front a History of Scotland ndash given he didnrsquot have a degree in history.Oliver didnrsquot take Devinersquos comment laying down however, describing the historian as being like of the old grumps from The Muppets.More recently, Oliver got it in the neck when appointed president of the National Trust for Scotland, and many Nationalists demanded his removal, which seemed odd given the TV presenterrsquos passion for this space we live in.But the writer presenter took it on broad shoulders. Did his personal history prepare him for the future stre  Seems so. Hersquos used to adjustment. ldquoI was born in a council flat in Renfrew, my dad moved to Ayr to work [he was a commission salesman] and then to Dumfries. The family was ldquocomfortable, he says. It certainly wasnrsquot an Angelarsquos Ashes set in Scotland storyline. They even managed a holiday to Spain once.Yet, the man who would go on to explain the Picts and Vikings and anacyclosis to uswasnrsquot top of the class at school. ldquoI was in the upper half but I wasnrsquot so great at maths and science so I focused on English and history, which I was quite good at.Oliver was blessed with encouraging parents who most likely were baffled why their son wanted to study archaeology, University I fell in love with the prospectus given it rarely leads to a career. ldquoI did work as an excavator for a few years going on digs, he recalls. ldquoIt was fun, but there was no money in it. And during the winters it became a bit grim.One Friday afternoon he was excavating the Roman Road in Greenock, and on the Monday he was covering a peace protest in Lockerbie for the local newspaper. Why the switch to journalism ldquoI liked the idea of journalism because it was essentially noseyness about people, he explains, grinning. ldquoItrsquos a bit like archaeology in that itrsquos the chance to poke through the rubbish, to find out what people were doing and why. Instinctively, I want to know who, what, where, why and when.Journalism has been as important to his current career, he says, as his time spent scraping dirt with a big spoon. ldquoWhen Irsquove been cast in the likes of Coast as a presenter it helped me get something out of people. And this Magpie-like work taught me how to become engrossed in a subject for a day then drop it, and move onto something .The curious mind continued to search for the next adventure and in  he joined a BT internet company. ldquoI thought that may be my future. I was also fascinated to learn how it had evolved, largely financed by the US military, who wanted to knowcomputers could survive after a nuclear attack. And so they hired these hippies to find out. And then I wondered what do we do with it  What are the consequences of it He answers his own question: ldquoItrsquos created titans such as Mark Zuckerberg, and Amazon, Google and Pay Pal. He adds in soft, serious voice, ldquoNow, Zuckerberg is almost at the point he has more power than Putin, without the missiles.While working for the internet company, Oliver decided to set off for Zululand.ldquoI had met up with my close pal from university Tony Pollard one day in the Granary Bar in Glasgowrsquos Shawlands and we came up with the idea of going to Zululand to make a film [which became the BBCrsquos  documentary, Two Men In A Trench].Boldness has to be part of the reason for Oliverrsquos success. He had a good job, with a good salary, a car and an Amex account. ldquoBut I didnrsquot have a mortgage. I wasnrsquot married. I could take a chance. And I knew I had had experience. When the TV job ran out Irsquod do something .Does the job flipping suggest a malcontent  ldquoNo, when I was at BT I figured Irsquod give it a couple of years, he says with a wee hint of umbrage in his voice for me having suggested such a thing. ldquoAnd we made the film really because we wanted to go to South Africa. The voice warms again: ldquoArchaeology was my first love and we met again. It was like Friends Reunited. And wersquove been together ever since.Hersquos a television natural. But did he always feel confident speaking to the camera  ldquoYes. Irsquove always had a good memory and Irsquom lucky in that I can remember  words in the right order, he says, grinning. ldquoTalking to the camera is not a natural thing to do. Itrsquos like a golf swing. But some people can do it. And I enjoyed being with these like-minded people. It was quite collegiate. I loved it from the get-go.Oliver landed on the box at the right time. ldquoI was   when television began to happen for me. I had few delusions about my own reality. Irsquod been in a few dferent jobs, had the rougher edges knocked off by le experience. Irsquod filled shelves at Presto supermarket while eating the Mars Bars. Irsquod worked on an MS till. He adds, with a wry smile, ldquoIrsquod been dumped often enough by women.Women. Yes, now hersquos married to one. And history taught him he should incorporate this woman into his future. Oliver met his future we Trudi when he was at university. ldquoI was in third year at the time, the president of the archaeology society and she was in first year, and she came in to join. I made a bee-line for her when she walked in the door.He grins. ldquoI donrsquot think she was as impressed by me as I was by her.She must have liked him a little because the pair were together for seven years. ldquoAnd it just sort of fizzled out. Then, years later, I met her wee brother Johnny and we swapped numbers and a few months after that I was back in touch with Trudi. It was asIrsquod seen her the day before.He reflects: ldquoThatrsquos another great thing about my le. Whatever happens, I know Irsquom with someone who remembers me when I was  and a silly arse. She remembers me when I had all sorts of archaeology student affectations, all patchouli oil and cheese cloth shirts. We can remember the teenagers we were.Oliver reveals he had the long hair back in the day. He didnrsquot create the soft Tarzan look for telly. He has just never bothered to have it cut. And it works for him, gives him a USP, although watching him on TV with the wind blasting into his face as he stands on a clf edge he does have to brush it away from his mouth a little too often but, I suppose, a kirby grip or a hair scrunchy would wreck the image.He laughs. ldquoIrsquove been holding out for the Head and Shoulders contract for  years but itrsquos never happened.Therersquos a calm about Oliver, even though he does become animated when he talks about the politics he says he wants nothing to do with. And he clearly loves his le, beaming at the delights of a career which allows him to take his family adventuring in the likes of Australia and New Zealand while filming Coast. Yet with three children hersquos not immune to worry, about the impact of social media, for example. ldquoPeople can have , friends, but ironically they have never been more isolated and lonelier. People go to Facebook ndash I donrsquot ndash hoping to see other people in this clearing in the forest who are equally lonely.Hersquos happy however, very happy. ldquoThe thing I most love these days is writing. I wrote as a student, as a journalist and then in TV with scripts. Irsquove written ten books or so and itrsquos something Irsquoll be able to do.And now hersquos making live appearances. ldquoIrsquove sort of blundered into them. Irsquom out there talking about our world, like Simon Reeve and Dan Snow. Maybe I can do this every year. Why not So the world will be all right, Neil  We need you to tell us it will be. ldquoWe tend to think this is a modern concern, but perhaps Stonehenge and Avebury are partly expressions of feeling the same concerns, people feeling they are little specks in the great scheme of things and wanting to be heard, to make a mark.He grins, reassuringly. ldquoWersquoll be fine, but I wonrsquot beI donrsquot do this school pick-up in time.Neil Oliver ndash The Story of the British Isles in  Places, the Theatre Royal, Glasgow, November .

title: scotlands-insider-guide-stornoway
story: But therersquos so much more to the Hebridean capital than just great views. Indeed, this bustling port on the Isle of Lewis has a thriving arts, culture and food scene that puts many bigger mainland towns to shame.Itrsquos also a place to soak up Gaelic hospitality, history and tradition, while appreciating the ever-changing terrains of this magical, wind-swept isle.Historical HighlightsKnown as Stjoacuternavaacutegr, or ldquosteering bay in Old Norse, Stornoway was founded by the Vikings in the early th century, people have inhabited Lewis for around  years.The main street, Cromwell Street, is named for Oliver Cromwell, whose forces fought to take control of the town in .Owned by the Mackenzies of Seaforth for more than  years, Lewis was sold to Sir James Matheson for pound, in . The new laird built Lews Castle, which still overlooks the bay, as well as many of the islandrsquos roads and schools.With its sheltered harbour and strategic location, Stornoway played a key role in both world wars. On New Yearrsquos Day , HMY Iolaire ndash Gaelic for eagle ndash sank in the harbour, killing at least  men ing home from the First World War.Oban guideAccording to the  census,  per cent of residents in greater Stornoway speak Gaelic. More than , people now live in the town, employed mainly in the tourism, textile, seafood and offshore industries.Things to doFirst things first, get your bearings with a jaunt around the harbour. Yoursquoll see boats of all shapes and sizes, from the huge CalMac ferry - Loch Seaforth - that transports locals and visitors to and from Ullapool, to fishing boats, leboats and pleasure crafts that populate the ious piers and marinas. The Sail Stornoway festival takes place every July, attracting hundreds of boats from all over Scotland and beyond.As you take in the sights and smells of the seafront there are plenty of places to stop for coffee, snacks or fish and chips. Itrsquos also worth walking up to the headland at the Holm Point end, where the poignant memorial to the Iolaire disaster stands.The walk along the seafront also takes you straight to An Lanntair , the arts, culture and community hub that opened in . A theatre, cinema, live music venue, art gallery, dance studio and more, it also has a fantastic cafeacute bar and shop, and with a full programme of events and exhibitions all year round, therersquos always something to see. Forthcoming highlights include the Dark Skies Festival, in February , which features an eclectic mix of music, visual art and science.Oban guideIts also well worth popping into the Town Hall to see the newly-installed Harris Tweed Story, told by the authoritythat certies the world-renowned fabric with its famous orb. Looms take centre stage alongside dferent types of products and a visual and audio guide that helps explain what makes the tweed, which can only be woven on Harris or Lewis, so special.Lews Castledeserves a whole day of your time. Home to the excellent Museum nan Eilean and some of the mysterious Lewis Chessmen, it has a full programme of exhibitions reflecting island le and history, including the current one, which focuses on the Iolaire. The stunning grounds, meanwhile, make for wonderful walking no matter the season, with the trees ndash a rarity on the island ndash providing welcome shelter from the wind. If yoursquore feeling lazy, a guided Segway touris the ideal way to whizz around. Therersquos a great cafeacute, too, which has ldquothe best scones in Stornoway, according to Jan Patience.Itrsquos worth remembering that many people on Lewis are very religious and consider Sunday to be a special day of the week. Most commercial activity stops, and the vast majority of businesses are closed, though ferries and flights now operate.Where to eatThe Cafeacute Bar at An Lanntair is a relaxed affair that serves delicious food from am till pm, complete with great sea views. The chowder, made with local ingredients, is a hearty meal in itself.Seafood fans are certainly spoiled for choice in Stornoway. Upmarket Digby Chick , run by chef-proprietor James Mackenzie, showcases the best of locally caught fish and shellfish. The Minch turbot served with mussels and chive butter is simply sensational, and the early bird menu offers great value at pound. for three courses.Oban guideIf itrsquos a good fish supper yoursquore after ndash and who isnrsquot  ndash Cameronrsquos on Point Street doesnrsquot disappoint. CalMac also serves up excellent fish and chips in comfortable surroundings on the ferry to and from Stornoway. The macaroni cheese also gets five-star reviews.HS- at the Royal Hotelon Cromwell Street offers tasty burgers and wraps, served in a cosmopolitan, buzzy atmosphere, and for those who like their food spicy, the popular Thai Cafeacute lets you bring your own bottle.For coffee and cake, Lewis resident Kathryn Lamont Smith is a big fan of the Blue Lobster on the waterfront. ldquoI love this place, she says. ldquoAs well as being my favourite cafeacute, it is also a lovely gt shop. Kopi Java, on Cromwell Street, meanwhile, pulls in locals and visitors alike with its gourmet coffee and hot chocolate. The empire biscuits arenrsquot half bad, either.Where to shopHarris Tweed Hebrideson Cromwell Street is the place to go for all your tweed needs, from beautul tailored jackets, trousers, waistcoats and skirts, to accessories and home interiors.The lovely Hebridean Hobby Centre , also on Cromwell Street, has a full range of crafting materials, from wools and fabrics to modelling kits.Yoursquoll also want to stock up on the local food before you leave, from the world famous, geographically protected Stornoway black pudding made by Charles MacLeodand sold from the shop in Ropework Park, to the exquisite smoked salmon from the family-run Stornoway Smokehouse on Shell Street .The Good Food Boutique , back on Cromwell Street, has an array of quality deli foods from home and abroad, and also serves great coffee.Where to stayLuxury: Natural Retreats Lews Castlehas beautul apartments in the castle grounds, overlooking the harbour, from pound a night.Mobile: You can be king of the Hebridean road in this modern camper van, complete with fitted kitchen, which sleeps four. Comes with parking. From pound a night. Listed on Airbnb.Famous facesBBC Scotland and Alba presenter Cathy Macdonald is from Stornoway, as is actor Hans Matheson, who has appeared in TV shows such as Tess of the DrsquoUrbervilles, The Tudors and Jericho.Hollywood screenwriter Aeneas Mackenzie, writer of films including They Died With Their Boots On, Ivanhoe  and The Ten Commandments, was born in Stornoway in .Things to do nearbyIf you do only one other thing on Lewis, visit the extraordinary Neolithic standing stones at Calanais,  miles west of Stornoway. Truly unforgettable.The amazingly preserved broch at Carloway,  miles from Stornoway, is more than  years old and offers a unique insight into Iron Age le.The stunning white sands at Uig, on the west coast of Lewis, seem to go on forever, rivalling even the best beaches on nearby Harris.

title: Iain Macwhirter  May   s done the impossible - brought Leave and Remainers together  but only against her
story: The Prime Minister made a dignied, resilient stand last week, before a House of Commons that loathes this proposal. But theres a time when resilience turns into defiance, and then defiance turns into delusion. Theresa Mayrsquos staying power is the nations curse, as she perseveres with a orce deal which has no hope. She has finally united Leavers and Remainers, but only to the extent that theyrsquore against her. Shes lost both her Brexit Secretaries, a host of ministers and both houses of parliament. But, like Monty Pythonrsquos limbless Black Knight, she battles on regardless.MPs on all sides say the European Court of Justice will continue to have effective jurisdiction over UK laws on things like state aid, labour conditions, environmental standards and tax. Theresa May insists it wonrsquot, and that by , a deep and meaningful future trading relationship will have been negotiated, which will make the backstop unnecessary. But that is a triumph of hope over experience. No one has yet come up with a way of ensuring frictionless trade that doesnt involve either membership of the Customs Union, or accepting many of the rules of the European Single Market. If you keep all or part of the single market you keep the ECJ.This doesnt mean that the ECJ is involved in every negotiation. There is to be an arbitration  to sort out everyday problems between the EU and UK. But when it comes to a dispute on EU law, the ECJ rulings are final. That is crystal clear in Article  of the Withdrawal Agreement which says that the ECJ ldquoshall have jurisdiction to make such a ruling, which will be binding on the arbitration .Theres nothing sinister in this ndash except in the eyes of paranoid europhobes. When you join a tennis club, no one complains that your rights and liberties are being removed just because you accept the rules. The real issue is whether you have any say in the making of them. Democracy demands that members of an international trading organisation should have have a share in the decision-making process. This is where the Withdrawal Agreement, indeed the whole Brexit project falls down, because as things stand, we dont. We will be rule takers.Theresa May realised very early on that the economic cost of leaving the EU completely was just too high. She gave assurances to all those big international companies like Nissan, Siemens and Rolls Royce, who have complex, just-in-time supply chains, that she would negotiate a deal that was at least as good as the single market. She effectively promised no tarfs, border checks or regulatory issues ndash ie no ldquofriction - between Britain and the EU. She had to, or theyd have upped and left . Components for Vauxhall cars are said to cross and recross EU borders at least  times before theyre finally assembled in Ellesmere Port.But removing tarf and non-tarf barriers is precisely what the Customs Union and the European Single Market were originally created to do. The EU is first of all a free trade area, the most comprehensive in the world. When Britain decided to leave, it meant that frictions would inevitably . Theresa May has been trying to square the circle ever since: getting the benefits of a single market without being in it.Shes achieved quite a lot, to give her credit. Under her orce deal, Britain gets broad access in to the single market in goods without having to accept free movement. But the cost was always going to be some continued observance of the EUrsquos regulations, plus ECJ oversight. Weve had to agree to ldquodynamic alignment with EU regulations, meaning that when they change in future Britain will have to go along with the new rules.The obvious solution might be to just join the single market, as Norway did after . It is not in the EU, the Common Fisheries Policy or the Common Agricultural Policy. This is Nicola Sturgeons preferred option, and she said last week thatScotland even got the same deal as Northern Ireland, which is to remain largely in the ESM, she would vote for the Withdrawal Agreement. But while this Norway option has worked after a fashion, it has powerful critics. It costs quite a lot, and there have long been complaints in Oslo about ldquofax democracy - that new laws are simply faxedfrom Brussels. But hey ndash thats just how these things work. You are either in the EU or you arent.So what happens now  Mays deal wont fly, yet she stands her ground. The deal will almost certainly be rejected in parliament, even though Labour dont really have a coherent alternative. Jeremy Corbyn was scathing about Mayrsquos ldquobotched deal, but he too wants to leave the EU. Nor do Labour wish Britain to be a formal member of the Customs Union or the European Single Market. John McDonnell, the Shadow Chancellor, says he would renegotiate the deal to achieve a ldquoclose and collaborative relationship with the single market. In other words, a better deal than Mayrsquos. But the German Chancellor, Angela Merkell, has made clear that negotiations are over. End of story.Faced with a disastrous no deal, and no prospect of renegotiating the Withdrawal Agreement, the opposition parties face a very hard parliamentary choice next month. Do they join with Jacob Rees Mogg and the DUP, and vote for an economic disaster which would damage the livelihoods of countless Labour voters  Or do they suck it up, back Theresa May and then blame the Tories in future for landing Britain with such a bad settlement  If they vote down Mayrsquos orce deal, they must know that renegotiation is not now an option. Nor is a general election, because the Tories wonrsquot vote, like turkeys, for an early Christmas. The only alternative is for the opposition parties to do what they should have done months ago: unite the Remain majority in the House of Commons to demand a delay on Article , and then force May to hold a repeat referendum.If parliament cant decide what to do, the only option is to hand it back to the people who got us into this mess in the first place: the voters.

title: the-cool-list-hotels
story: Built in  by Lord MacDonald of Sleat and once surrounded by orange trees ndash hence the hotelrsquos name ndash Marmalade is a -minute walk from Portree harbour and offers fine views over Portree Bay and to the Cuillins beyond. Butthe exterior is resolutely Georgian, the interior is st century to the max ndash the  rooms have a chic, pared-back Scandinavian feel and a colour palette of mustard and grey. As the name suggests, the hotelrsquos Chargrill Restaurant specialises in grilled steak and seafood and therersquos an emphasis on locally-grown and locally-sourced produce. That ethos extends beyond the dining room: many of the hotel textiles, such as the throws which cover the beds, are made by local company Skye Weavers on their bicycle-powered looms. How cool is that Fingal, EdinburghBuilt in  by the Scotstoun-based Blythswood yard, the Leith-registered MV Fingal spent most of its working le as a Northern Lighthouse Board ship working out of Oban and Stromness. And now that it has been ed to Leith and berthed near to the Royal Yacht Britanniaitrsquos seeing out its days as hellip a luxury hotel of course, what   Each cabin is named after a Stevenson lighthouse but therersquos more than a touch of old-style ocean liner luxury to the rooms. Asthat wasnrsquot the perfect excuse to unleash your inner Bing Crosby or Ginger Rogers therersquos also a magnicent ballroom with a sweeping staircase. Just one snag, though: after a delay in gaining the green light from the capitalrsquos planning panjandrums, the hotel wonrsquot now open until January.Isle of Eriska Hotel  Spa, ObanWho hasnrsquot wanted to live on their own private island  At the Isle of Eriska Hotel you can,only for a few nights ndash covering  acres itrsquos located at the mouth of Loch Creran,  miles north of Oban, and offers fine views over Loch Linnhe and the Morvern mountains beyond. There are  bedrooms in the main house, built by acclaimed Scottish architect Hippolyte Blanc in  for a branch of the Stewarts of Appin, as well as five spa suites in the garden, two cottages and six ldquohilltop reserves complete with hot tubs and balconies. The sumptuous dining room specialises in game and seafood and therersquos a cornucopia of spa treatments on offer as well as a -metre swimming pool, a sauna, a steam room, a jacuzzi and a gym. Andyoursquore the time-poor, cash-rich sort that takes leisure seriously and isnrsquot prepared to waste time travelling, the hotel can accommodate helicopters and sea planes. Tides permitting, of course.Bauhaus Hotel and Kitchen, AberdeenDesigned by the late Edinburgh-born architect Bob Fitzgerald, this chic city centre hotel was inspired by the simplicity and famously clean lines of Germanyrsquos Bauhaus art school. The homage even extends to the names of the rooms ndash here you can stay in suites named after Walter Gropiusand Wassily Kandinsky , as well as other early th century design luminaries such as husband-and-we team Charles and Ray Eames, of Eames chair fame. Art history lessons aside, therersquos a bar serving cocktails and afternoon tea, though the hotel kitchen serves only breakfast. For anything  yoursquoll have to hit the streets, though the hotelrsquos central location means yoursquore spoiled for choice.Blythswood Square Hotel, GlasgowIts not unusual for the stars to stay in Glasgows only five star hotel when in town, with Sir Tom Jones a recent guest. The seven storey hotel now boasts a luxury two bedroom penthouse apartment, complete with private lt, wet room, dining room and roof garden. For a real taste of how the other half le, you can even avail yourself of the services of a private chef and butler. If your budget doesnt quite stretch to the pound, tag, however, the hotel - once townhouses owned by the citys wealthy merchants - has more than  bedrooms . After sipping a cocktail or two in the elegant Salon, guests can treat themselves in the spa, or even get a haircut with a barber shop and beauty salon on site.Greywalls, East LothianBuilt in  in the Arts and Craft style by the celebrated Edwardian architect Sir Edwin Lutyens and used as a country house by several well-heeled owners, among them the Hon. Alfred Lyttelton and Scottish-American socialite Evelyn Forbes, Greywalls also served as a military hospital during the second world war. It wasnrsquot until  that it became a hotel by which point it had been added to by another famous architect, Sir Robert Lorimer, and had had a garden laid out by the inestimable Gertrude Jekyll. She also designed the amazing garden overlooking Lindisfarne Castle on Lindisfarne, another Lutyens project. Itrsquos no surprise, then, that today Greywalls is a Category A-listed building with prices to match. Handy for the adjacent Muirfield golf course and renowned for its restaurantitrsquos easily one of Scotlandrsquos coolest hotels. King Edward VII, Barbra Streisand and Brigitte Bardot certainly thought so: theyrsquore just a few of the celebrities who have stayed there.Monachyle Mhor, Lochearnhead, PerthshireFancy ditching the traditional hotel room and staying instead in a s Pilot Panther showmanrsquos wagon  Or how about the old waiting room from the Port Appin to Isle of Lismore ferry, renovated and repurposed and turned into a cosy double located next to a chic bothy with a wood-burning stove designed by two architecture students  Trip along to Monachyle Mhor and you can lay your head in these and other dwellings, each as cool and quirky as the rest. There are six ldquofeature rooms, six courtyard rooms, and four whitewashed and coolly spartan farmhouse rooms. The hip factor doesnrsquot stop there, either. The award-winning restaurant uses locally-sourcedproduce and the Lewis family who own Monachyle Mhor also have their own bakery turning out that artisan sourdough wersquore all so fond of these days.Z Glasgow, GlasgowLocated just off George Square in a converted print works and boasting  rooms, Z Glasgow is one of a group of similarly-named hotels with several branches in Londonas well as in Liverpool and Bath. Z Glasgowrsquos mission statement makes clear itrsquos aimed unashamedly at what it calls ldquourbanites rather than tourists, and truth to tell the rooms arenrsquot massive. Then again, urbanites donrsquot visit Glasgow to sit around watching Cash In The Attic ndash they go there to shop, visit top cultural destinations such as the nearby Gallery of Modern Art and to sample the legendary nightle. They tend to eat out as well, so Z Glasgow dispenses with room service and provides Z Cafeacute instead offering breakfasts, light lunches and pre-theatre drinks.Crossbasket Castle, BlantyreFormerly a Barnardorsquos home, an educational college, a centre for a Pentacostal ministry and at one time the residence of Charles Macintosh of raincoat fame, this grand old building was restored in  and now boasts a Roux Brothers restaurantand bills itself as one of Scotlandrsquos most luxurious hotels. Few who visit would argue. Prime among the palatial suites is one with its own tower, though you can also choose to stay in the less grandiose Gate Lodge. The grounds, meanwhile, contain river-side nature walks and therersquos even a waterfall thoughyou want to venture further afield, you can arrange to have a Range Rover delivered direct to the hotel. Theyrsquoll even lay on a helicopteryou need one.Corsewall Lighthouse Hotel, Dumfries and GallowayLocated in the northern Rhinns of Galloway and still a working lighthouse, Corsewall offers a ied selection of suites and rooms both in the main building itself and in adjacent buildings. Built in  and now A-listed it offers views of the Kintyre peninsula, Ailsa Craig and, on a clear day, the coast of Ireland. Itrsquos ideal for golfersas well as birdwatchers and walkers drawn by the rugged coastline. And, of course, it will appeal to lighthouse nerds: at night you can see the beams of several Scottish and Irish lighthouses and both Mull of Galloway and Killantringan light houses are a short drive away. The restaurant is small but comfortable and typical dishes include Galloway pork fillet, smoked chicken, Scotch beef and roast monkfish.Tigerlily, EdinburghSited in a grand Georgian building on George Street in Edinburghrsquos New Town, this boutique hotel is one of the capitalrsquos liveliest upmarket spots ndash expect to find footballers partying in the bar alongside the hip visitors and well-heeled locals. It has a -strong cocktail menu overseen by an award-winning ldquomixologist and next door in the restaurant you can take afternoon tea or sample a menu that runs from the comfortingto the indulgent . Upstairs the rooms are coolly elegant, thoughitrsquos character you want head for The Black Room. Located at the top of the building it has walls the colour of ebony and one of those iconic s-style wicker ldquoegg chairs suspended from the ceiling by a chain.

title: the-herald-diary-no-catheter-coffee-for-us-please
story: THE Herald reported that parents groups and charities are calling for the trend of giving teachers Christmas presents from pupils to be stopped because it puts families under financial pressure. It reminds us of the primary teacher in Drumchapel who had been given the usual pile of chocolates and bubble bath from her class when one of her more colourful -year-olds sidled up, confiding: "Ah wis gauny get ye a Christmas present, miss . . . but ahm no auld enough tae go in the shop and buy a bottle of Lambrini fur ye."Takes the biscuitSAYS Bob Stewart: "Your items on cute remarks by children reminded me that recently our four-year-old great-granddaughter was caught by her mother raiding the biscuit tin. On receiving the inevitable scolding the little one retorted, Mummy! You have to learn to share!"Sized him upBBC newsreader Richard Baker has died at the age of . He wrote in his biography about the shock of newsreaders becoming personalities and being stopped in the street by the public who asked for autographs. He did add though that once in Glasgow someone in the street saw him and cried: "It is! Its no!" The fan then reached the loud conclusion: "It is! Wee fatty!"Mums the wordAUTHOR Barbra Paskin has just published a book on the late entertainer Dudley Moore, entitled Dear Dudley, which includes copies of the many letters that celebrities sent him to cheer him up on his th birthday when he was ill. We liked the one from Des OConnor who reminded Dudley in his letter: "I remember you telling me what your mum said when she saw you nude in the film . Oh Dud, I saw all your bits and pieces and I havent seen those since you were a baby... and you havent changed a bit. Im still getting laughs in concerts with that story."Cup runneth overTHE word came up in a Diary story yesterday and reminded Margaret Thomson: "I was visiting a friend, and she asked her daughter to make coffee for us. Will I make instant or catheter coffee  asked the girl. We opted for instant!"Doggy taleGREAT to see the statue unveiled at Saltcoats to Celtics unassuming Lisbon Lion Bobby Lennox. We recall that when Bobby produced his autobiography, Thirty Miles From Paradise, he was doing a signing in a Dundee bookshop where a Celtic fan came in with two German Shepherds. Staff were about to tell him about their no-dogs policy when the chap told Bobby: "I named them after you ndash Bobby and Lennox."Bobby was well chuffed, until the publishers representative with him said: "I was going round book signings with Rangers John Greig last year and we met lots of guys who had been named Greig after their fathers hero ndash you only got dugs!"Just pantsEVEN though I was typing furiously to get this written for the deadline, it didnt stop a colleague from coming over and interrupting. When I finally looked up he declared: "My we hates it when I put her chocolate bars in other sweet wrappers."I just stare until he adds: "It gets her Snickers in a Twix."Butter them upWE mentioned being posh in Glasgows west end, and a reader there reminisces: "In the old days the description of posh was when one used the butter kne even when dining alone. How things change."

title: sturgeon-voices-degree-of-optimism-over-michelin
story: The First Minister spoke after discussions with trade unions from the tyre factory, where  jobs are at risk.Michelin has announced plans to cease production at the -year-old plant, blaming cheap imports from Asia and a sht to bigger cars for hitting the market for premium smaller tyres.The Scottish and UK governments are part of a -strong action group looking at ways to keep the plant viable, perhaps by repurposing it to make other products.Referring to SNP government grants and loans for other struggling large employers, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoFinding a way forward for the plant will not be easy but... it is important we explore every option."When it is necessary we are prepared to take a very active approach to helping to save jobs and preserve manufacturing bases."In the case of Michelin, none of us can guarantee success and it would be wrong to give workers a  expectation.ldquoI think there is reason to have a degree of optimism about the future of that site and about the future of those who work in that site."Economy Secretary Derek Mackay, who convened the Michelin Dundee Action Group, said: ldquoIn the coming days we will finalise our strategic proposition before presenting it to Michelin management.

title: nicola-sturgeon-poised-for-downing-st-showdown-with-theresa-may-as-brexit-tensions-rise
story: In another critical week for her premiership, the Prime Minister continues to face the threat of a no-confidence vote by Tory rebels last night she held private talks with Brexiteers and former Cabinet ministers Iain Duncan Smith and Owen Paterson to quell the rebellion.However, by this morning, the  signatures needed to trigger the ballot were still not forthcoming only  Conservative MPs have publicly admitted to handing in letters calling for a vote.This morning, Mrs May chaired Cabinet,facingdown any calls from colleagues to tweak the withdrawal agreement. She will visit Brussels tomorrowto meet Jean-Claude Juncker, the Commission President, to try to sign off the future framework dealahead of Sundays special EU summit.The First Minister, beforeher scheduled meeting with Mrs May today, claimed the PMrsquos insistence that the choice before MPs between her draft withdrawal agreement and a no-deal was a  one.ldquoThis is a time for grown-up, responsible governance in the public interest, declared Ms Sturgeon, ldquosomething which has been sadly lacking to date as the Tory Party has continued to put its own interests ahead of the interests of jobs, communities and businesses.ldquoIt mustnrsquot be an option between frying pan or fire but it is now incumbent on all of us who oppose that  choice to propose a workable alternative.The FM is also due to have a private Commons meeting with Labour leader Jeremy Corbynthis lunch-time to push a united front for continued single market and customs union membership as an alternative to a no-deal scenario.To the same end, she is also due to hold talks with Sir Vince Cable, the Liberal Democrat leader, Liz Saville Roberts for Plaid Cymru and Caroline Lucas for the Greens. The issue of pushing for a Peoples Vote is also likely to come up.Last night, Labourrsquos Sir Keir Starmer said Labour could even try to bring down the Conservative Government to block a no-deal Brexit.The Shadow Brexit Secretary told the Parliamentary Labour Party he was prepared to ldquowork with all sides to prevent the UK crashing out of the EU without a deal."There will be opportunities to make the majority against no-deal heard. Motions will be tabled, amendments will be pressed and a no-confidence vote can be triggered.If a no-confidence motion passed, a new government would have to be formed within  days and win its own confidence voteit failed, there would be a general election.In Whitehall yesterday, the SNPrsquos Michael Russell, attending his th Joint Ministerial Committee, brushed aside questions about Ms Sturgeon calling for a second independence referendum, insisting the ldquofirst priority was to stop what he branded a disastrous withdrawal agreement.Claiming UK ministers had lost ldquoall sense of reason, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Constitutional Relations Secretary declared: ldquoIt is an emergency for all the nations in these islands to stop this deal.But, post the fiery JMC, Mr Mundell launched a withering attack on the motives of the SNP leadership.Claiming the worst possible outcome for Scotland and the UK would be a no-deal, he declared: ldquoWhat the SNP are looking to achieve is chaos...because they believe thatrsquos the best way to take forward their independence agenda.He added: ldquoIf there is a majority in the House of Commons against this deal, we risk a no-deal Brexit and a disastrous outcome for Scotland.Mr Mundell was also pressed on the issue of including UK fishing rights in any extension to the -month transition period.ldquoIm very clear we cant extend the period and include the Common Fisheries Policy within that extension and I could not support that, he insisted.Askedhe would therefore resignBritain remained bound by CFP rules beyond December , the Secretary of State replied: ldquoIm not playing into the resign soap opera. What Im focused on is outcomes and we want the best outcome for Scotland."Earlier on Monday, the PM, following a speech to the CBI, pointed to the possibility of extending the transition period but noting how this should not go beyond the General Election scheduled for June .While the draft withdrawal agreement simply points to both sides using their ldquobest endeavours to get a post-transition agreement on fishing by June , No  admitted the issue of UK fishing rights would be part of the negotiations.ldquoThese are all things that would have to be discussed, said a spokesman.

title: neil-mackay-why-climate-change-should-be-the-only-story-that-matters
story: I am taking it for granted that readers believe in climate change ndash know for a fact that itrsquos real ndash and so Irsquom not going to rehearse the science, which has been long established and proven. If anyone doubts the truth of climate change, the queue to join the Flat Earth Society is just over there.If you believe in climate change then you should fear it ndash and I donrsquot just mean worry about it when you hear the words on the news, I mean dread it, be terried by it on an existential level, or perhaps a mass extinction level. If you donrsquotndashyou sit and fret about Brexit or Scottish independence more than you do the planetrsquos rising temperature -ndashthen you may as well be worrying about your mortgage repayments while therersquos a killer in your house with a gun at your childrsquos head.More and more people are getting this: that the only really important question facing the human race is how we ensure that the planet survives so our children and grandchildren can grow old, live well and be happy. At the weekend in London, thousands of demonstrators carried out one of the biggest acts of mass civil disobedience in the UK in decades in an attempt to hammer into the thick skulls of our political leaders that climate change matters above all . It got little news coverage.Around  people were arrested after blocking Londonrsquos main bridges. The demonstrators ndash part of the new organisation Extinction Rebellion ndash will continue the disruption tomorrow, when activists will converge on central London. I wish they were doing the same in Glasgow or Edinburgh, because I quite fancy handcuffing myself to some railings with them.The basis of their anger and fear is not only sound and incontrovertible, but morally just. Each one of us should be acting, or at least speaking up. In October, the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Changesaid there are now just  years to avert planetary disaster. Twelve years ndash cosmologically thatrsquos the blink of an eye. Twelve years ago, Tony Blair was Prime Minister. Menzies Campbell replaced Charles Kennedy as LibDem leader. Daniel Craig debuted as Bond. Oh, and Europe was hit by a heatwave giving the UK its hottest July on record. The shape of things to come, eh Did you hear much about that IPCC report  Did newspapers clear  pages to give you every spit and cough of the findings  Did the TV news run extended reports  Did Parliament ndash any parliament ndash go into special session  We have a dozen years ndash until  ndash in which to keep global warming to a maximum of .C. If we go even a half a degree above that then drought, floods and heatwaves will mean death and poverty for millions. Coral reefs could be completely eradicated.Read more: Climate change activists block London bridgesWith the world now C warmer than pre-industrial levels, the IPCC made clear that the hurricanes, droughts and forest fires we are seeing around the world is climate change happening before our very eyes. There have even been forest fires in Lapland in the Artic circle. At .C the proportion of the worldrsquos population exposed to water shortages would be  per cent lower than at C. Food would not become as scarce with a .C rise than with a C rise. Hundreds of millions more people will be thrust into poverty with a C rise than a .C rise. Heat-related deaths would also increase, insects would lose half their natural habitat, sea-level rise would affect  million more people, marine fisheries would crash. At current rates, though, the world is possibly headed for C worth of warming.Almost  senior British academics back Extinction Rebellionrsquos campaign of civil disobedience, and the former Archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams has thrown his hat into the ring with them as well. These experts say that the failure of politicians to tackle climate change has broken the ldquosocial contract between government and the people. In an open letter they said it was their right to ldquobypass the Governmentrsquos inaction and flagrant dereliction of duty and to rebel to defend le itself.We live in the era of the short attention span ndash news cycles come in a blizzard, stories swirl and dissipate with the wind before they are properly told ndash and climate change is a slow-moving catastrophe. It is hard to see ndash it requires reading, thought and consideration. Climate change does not appear on TV with silly blond hair spouting about theof pound million from the EU to the NHS climate change does not endlessly bicker about independence climate change does not cause a punch-up on Twitter over trans rights or someone dressed as Hitler.Who cares about whether we are in or out of Europethe world is starting to burn  What is Scottish independence worthno-one is putting the fire out  Why should I worry about what anyone on social media saysthe people typing away will be lucky to be alive in  yearsrsquo time  Perhaps, the only national or international story that really matters apart from climate change is Donald Trump ndash as his policies, his fetishisation of coal and dirty industries, compounds global warming.Many have described events such as Brexit as ldquosuicidal or ldquoan act of national self-harm. Weighed in the balance against climate change, it is the equivalent of comparing stubbing your toe to slitting your own throat.The climate rebels want a few simple things ndash a commitment by the Government to reduce carbon emissions to zero by  and a ldquocitizens assembly to devise an emergency plan of action similar to that seen during the Second World War. As one young woman who attended the London demo, named Alice, said: ldquoThis moment will be remembered in the history books, when we finally stopped allowing our leaders to take us over a clf. Pray she is right.

title: margaret-taylor-best-hope-the-return-of-cameron-would-bring-no-hope
story: There may be some kind of twisted logic to the idea that Mr Cameron should be forced back to clean up a political mess that is pretty much entirely of his making, but woe betide ushe does. For while Labour grandee Peter Mandelson famously said that history would remember Mr Cameron ldquosimply as the prime minister who took us out of the EU, the legacy of another of the former member for Witneyrsquos bright ideas - austerity - shows just how unfit for office he really is.Dreamed up by Mr Cameron and fellow Bullingdon BoyGeorge Osborne - who, inexplicably, has reinvented himself as the Tory-bashing newspaper editor par excellence - austerity was announced in  as the antidote to the Labour Partyrsquos preceding ldquoage of irresponsibility. With the country brought low by unscrupulous bankers and misguided borrowers - not to mention profligate Labour politicians - the time had apparently come for us all to tighten our belts for the good of the nation.Yet while Mr Osbornersquos ldquowersquore all in this together mantra rang hollow right from the off, the extent to which austerity has ravaged the poor while allowing the rich to amble along just fine was last week laid bare in a damning report from the UN rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights, Philip Alston. Indeed, thanks to austerity measures such as the introduction of what Mr Alston termed ldquoUniversal Discredit,  million people in the UK are now living in poverty, with the poor, women, racial and ethnic minorities, children, single parents, and people with disabilities most severely affected. Not only is this shameful in a nation that boasts the worldrsquos fth largest economy but, as Mr Alston said, it is ldquopatently unjust and contrary to British values.Nor can Scotland claim the moral high ground. Though the UN report noted that we have the lowest poverty rates of any UK nation, Scottish Government figures show that the number of people living in relative poverty north of the Border has increased by  per cent since the advent of austerity, from , in   to a million in  , , of whom are children. And while the Alston report praised measures such as the Scottish Governmentrsquos Fairer Scotland Action Plan and said its nascent benefits agency is ldquoguided by the principles of dignity and social security as a human right, the author stressed that accountability has not been written into the system while no mechanism is in place to ensure the most vulnerable can access what assistance is available to them.When he announced his age of austerity David Cameron said the intention was to show that ldquofiscal responsibility can go hand in hand with a social conscience. It is about as far from a ringing endorsement as you can get that Mr Alston has found the exact opposite to be the case, with his report highlighting that ldquoBritish compassion for those who are suffering has been replaced by a punitive, mean-spirited, and often callous approach apparently designed to instil discipline where it is least useful, to impose a rigid order on the lives of those least capable of coping with todayrsquos world, and elevating the goal of enforcing blind compliance over a genuine concern to improve the wellbeing of those at the lowest levels of British society. Whether or not the policy has been ldquofiscally responsible, meanwhile, remains moot.Asall that wasnrsquot bad enough, Warwick University economics professor Thiemo Fetzer published a paper earlier this year that drew a direct link between austerity and Brexit, with the deep cuts to welfare from  onwards thought to be responsible for pushing many in the UKrsquos most disadvantaged communities into the arms of UKIP and the vote-Leave camp. Sold on the promise of a new dawn of Great British prosperity, those voters - like the rest of us - are now forced to live in a country so economically damaged that the Financial Times reckons the average household is pound a year worse off than it was before the vote. What that figure will be once we make our final, shambolic exit from the European Union is anyonersquos guess, though we can all rest assured that it is highly unlikely to be heading south.Given his role in getting us into this mess, the idea that Mr Cameron is our best hope for getting out of it is far-fetched in the extreme. Whether he meant to or not, our former prime minister inflicted great misery on the UK the day he declared a new age of austerity, with his Brexit gamble only serving to compound the effect.The Tory Party under Theresa May may be intent on ripping itself ndash and the country ndash apart right now, but Mr Cameron is not the answer. Austerity and Brexit are indefensible allowing him to heap yet more misery on the people of the UK would be utterly unforgivable.

title: theresa-may-off-to-brussels-to-complete-brexit-deal-with-jean-claude-juncker
story: Downing Street said the meeting was part of the "ongoing negotiations over the future framework" agreement with the EU.It is understood the talks are set to focus on future long-term relations between the UK and EU, rather than on the withdrawal deal that the Prime Minister unveiled last week.The move follows a stormy few days for Mrs May, which have seen the DUP deliver a warning shot across Government bows after accusing her of breaking fundamental promises on Brexit.And a number of Tory MPs are still pushing for a vote of confidence in the PM, although their attempts to topple her appear, for the moment, to have stalled.David Gauke, the Justice Secretary, said a move to oust Mrs May would be "dangerous for the country".He told BBC Breakfast: "The idea that at this point, in the middle of a very delicate negotiation, that is hugely important to the future of this country, that we should remove the Prime Minister, essentially leave us leaderless, for certainly several weeks, possibly months, would be hugely irresponsible."I dont think people should be talking about removing her at this point. That would be self-indulgent and dangerous for the country."In another cause for concern for the PM, Mrs Mays Spanish counterpart Pedro Sanchez said Madrid would vote against the withdrawal deal at a special EU summit on SundayGibraltars future was not considered a bilateral issue between the UK and Spain.ldquoIn the past  hours, none of the documents has claried something which is fundamental for us: Gibraltar is not part of the UK, declared Mr Sanchez.ldquoAs a country, we cannot assume what is going to happen in the future with regard to GibraltarhellipIt should be negotiated between Spain and the UK. As it stands, the [Spanish] government will vote against the Brexit agreement," insisted the socialist leader in Madrid.Meanwhile, the DUP showed its anger with Mrs Mays Brexit deal by joining with Labour to cut the Governments majority to just five in a Commons vote on the Budget.It also abstained on a series of other amendments to the Finance Bill on Monday night, in a move intended to send a "political message" to the PM.Their actions appeared to call into question the future of the "confidence and supply" arrangement by which the DUP props up Mrs Mays minority Conservative Government.Under the terms of the deal, agreed after the Tory leader lost her Commons majority in last years General Election, the Northern Ireland party is supposed to back the Government on Budget matters and on confidence votes.But Sammy Wilson, the partyrsquos Brexit spokesman, said Mrs Mays deal with Brussels breached a "fundamental" assurance that Northern Ireland would not be separated constitutionally or economically from the rest of the UK."We had to do something to show our displeasure," he declared.In a bid to sway opinion, Mrs May has insisted that her draft Brexit deal puts Northern Ireland in a "fantastic position" for the future.In an opinion piece published in the Belfast , the PM claimed the regions constitutional status within the UK had been guaranteed in the agreement.Mrs May acknowledged that there had been a lot of focus on the Irish border "backstop" and said she "understood and share some of the concerns that have been expressed".But she argued the backstop was an "acceptable insurance policy" due to provisions in the deal.The DUP warning adds to the pressure on the PM just as the Tory bid to unseat her by Brexiteers appeared to have stuttered.Members of the Conservative European Research Group were last week confidently predicting they would get the  letters of no confidence needed to trigger a vote in her leadership.However, there has been no announcement from Sir Graham Brady, the Chairman of the backbench  Committee, saying that they have reached that tally, while the number of MPs who have publicly declared they submitted letters remains in the twenties.There were also reports that the so-called "pizza club" group of Cabinet Brexiteers was backing away from a plan to go to Mrs May to demand she re-opens negotiations with Brussels on a key element of the agreement.Michael Gove - who last week turned down the job of Brexit Secretary following the resignation of Dominic Raab - Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt, Liam Fox and Chris Grayling were all reported to be unhappy with the terms over the Northern Irish border.However, there was little sign that they were preparing to force a fresh showdown at the weekly meeting of the Cabinet in Downing Street on Tuesday, which was expected to last longer than the usual hour due to the circumstances.Elsewhere, in a further sign of the Governments weakness, ministers were forced to offer fresh concessions to stave off a damaging defeat over the publication of the Governments assessment of the economic impact of Brexit.Robert Jenrick, the Treasury Minister, told MPs they would now release a comparative analysis of the economic impactBritain was to remain in the EU rather than leave in March .Previously, the Government had only undertaken to publish its assessment of the impact of leaving with a deal, compared with a no-deal Brexit.

title: pioneering-project-in-alcoholism-treatment-goes-global
story: The scheme, which was first pioneered in the city seven years ago, is now being adopted in medical centres as far afield as the United States, Singapore and Australia.It comes as the Scottish Government unveiled plans for a TV watershed for alcohol adverts and cigarette-style health warning labels on alcohol packaging amid the latest figures showing that more than , Scots were hospitalised for their drinking last year.The Glasgow Modied Alcohol Withdrawal Score project was piloted in   to safely manage patients with alcohol withdrawal syndrome across Greater Glasgow and Clyde.People who have consumed alcohol heavily over a prolonged period, especially several years, are at risk of a range of symptoms - some of them severe - when they stop drinking.In the most serious cases, around % of patients will experience vivid hallucinations and delusions, but milder symptoms of withdrawal also include fever, high blood pressure, sweating, confusion, vomiting, insomnia, anxiety, shakiness and a racing heartbeat.As a result, patients are at increased risk of aggressive outbursts during withdrawal.The scoring system is based on identying and rating patients risk according to five symptoms and then tailoring their treatment according to their score.The initiative also pooled expertise from medical, nursing and pharmacy staff and enabled clinicians to spot patients in danger of withdrawal eventhey had presented at hospital for an unrelated injury or illness.Read more: Public at high risk of harm from environmental health cutsIn its first year, the number of alcohol-related violent incidents in Glasgow Royal Infirmary fell by %. By  , the hospital had reduced these episodes by % compared to  , the year before the scheme was implemented.It also cut the duration of patients average stay in hospital by % from five and a half to four and a half days, freeing up acute hospital beds earlier at a time when wards are busier than ever.Ewan Forrest, a consultant liver specialist, said: "The Score has enabled early identication of patients at risk of Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome as many patients at risk of this may present to hospital for reasons other than alcohol-related illness."This fundamental change to our treatment transformed patient management with reductions in hospital stay and greater patient safety. This is being picked up by other health boards across the UK and is also recognised internationally."Read more: School strikes threat as teachers reject pay dealIt comes at the latest figures for   revealed that there were more than  alcohol-related hospital admissions a day in Scotland, involving , iniduals.The number of alcohol-related admissions has fallen by a fth over the past decade, but the statistics also showed that the admissions rate was seven times higher among patients from the most deprived areas compared to those from the most affluent postcodes.Yesterday, Scotlands Public Health Minister Joe FitzPatrick unveiled a new -point plan to tackle harmful drinking, including a call to ban of alcohol advertising before the pm watershed.Laws on marketing are reserved to Westminster, however, so the Scottish Government will push UK ministers to include alcohol in its forthcoming ban on pre-watershed advertising of junk food.If not, calls for those powers to be devolved to Holyrood will be made so action can be taken north of the border.Earlier this week, experts called for a ban on alcohol advertising during winter after research found a link between colder, dark climates and excess drinking.Businesses are also being asked to place health information on their products. Mr FitzPatrick said he will also look at what legislation can be introducedmanufacturers do not voluntarily comply by September .Speaking at the European Alcohol Policy Conference in Edinburgh, Mr Fitzpatrick said: "Weve got % higher consumption of alcohol than the rest of the UK - and the UK is about the worst in western Europe, so we have our issues that we need to resolve."I dont think theres been any clear evidence as to why Scotlands relationship with alcohol is so challenging but it is - so we have to do something about it."
